author: {'steamid': '76561197973433720', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 4660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 690, 'last_played': 1693769206}
review:
This is difficult to review because there is a lot to like about this game, but there's also so much to frown upon. The setup and premise of the game are great. The game looks great, the ships look great, gameplay is good. For that alone I would say it's worth the buy. As one of the other reviews says: this game fills a niche that a lot of people have been waiting for.

So what's wrong then?
Controlling the ship just feels a little bit off, like maybe there was not enough time or thought put into that. 
Camera controls are a little bit awkward, why can't I ever find that ship that is somewhere next to me? There's also no zoom out to find it.
Dialog interface is not amazing, but maybe I've been spoilt by Mass Effect (same music, hence the comparison). 
Learning about which weapons to equip is trial and error, there is no guidance there.
Default keybinds make no sense at all, very unintuitive.
And last but not least: my pc is well above requirements, but for some reason the game needs 100% of my CPU. not GPU, CPU. so much so that after a while it will break the system and things just stop working.

On average though it's still worth the buy. You'll be annoyed at times sure, but you'll also have fun

author: {'steamid': '76561197975744062', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 113, 'playtime_forever': 2479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2479, 'last_played': 1616414681}
review:
This game is much improved over Starpoint Gemini 2.  Whilst many of the controls are the same, the layout of the UI, the graphics, and presentation deliver a better experience and makes it easier to engage in navigation, combat, and ship boarding.  The story was also better than the previous version.  It is a political intrigue story with slightly more believable and better voice acted characters, whereas, the predecessor and successor titles have blatantly terrible main characters and story.  Warlords is the middle child that does it better than either of its siblings.

Economy.
In games like X3 and Freelancer, there was a bit of market simulation and competition, so one had to hurry to those stations to buy and sell wares at the best prices.  That isn't the case here.  Prices are static.  Once you learn of the best prices, you simply get the best transport and run a route that is calculated to return the most money in the shortest amount of time.  Once the Prosperity is unlocked, trade deals net around 40 million credits a pop.  If you use T-drives, this can be done very quickly.  Once you make a few hundred million credits, you won't need to make money anymore.  The campaign will provide everything you need from then on.  Stations will also restock by the time you get back from your sales run, furthering the exploit.

Simply put, there is no economic simulation in this game.

Exploration.
The map is based on the Gemini solar system, a twin star system.  There are a bunch of terraformed worlds in this system, most of which are linked to a teleport gate network to allow for rapid transit between worlds.  There are many stations, more gates and wormholes to allow for rapid movement.  Otherwise, you are using sublight and travelling for a short time until you reach your destination.  In short, you aren't exploring the unknown, but, learning for yourself well established sectors of controlled space.  With good graphics hardware and draw distance, you simply navigate the 2d grid based map in a standard search pattern, as everything is on the solar ecliptic, then point your ship at a planet or station until you have everything found.

Searching down those relics is easy because you will find them on your map when you happenstance by them and can T-jump to them on the 2d map, scan, and get your upgrade points.  As for various other salvage, cargo containers, anomalies, encounters, pirates, etc, once you've seen one, you've seen them all.  They are helpful in the early game, but it becomes cookie cutter, redundant, and not worth the time investment later on.  I began ignoring all those things because I got everything I needed from trading exploitation.

You will not get lost, or feel like a space explorer.  Civilization is never that far from your current position.

Story.
The story is a cliche colonize and betrayal story, but better than SPG2 and 3's ridiculous main characters.  Overall, it's OK.  I was rather annoyed with it at times because the events were rather predictable and cliche.

You belong to a foreign Imperial remnant faction in the solar system and the locals don't seem to like you, except practically every major barony or corporate power.  You fight mostly annoying pirates that seem to randomly spawn right on top of you whenever you transition jump to another area.  The characters are more believable this time around.  You aren't some daddy's little boy or playboy grand child.  You are just an Imperial commander and you can choose the male or female version.  

The story is mission driven, and is quite easy to complete if you exploited trading and unlocked the Prosperity Titan class ship.

Strategy Map.
I first started on normal mode in both game difficulty and strategic difficulty.  However, at level 20, when I ran my cruiser and small fleet into enemy territory to take what appeared to be an unguarded defense node in a small territory on my border, a massive enemy fleet spawned out of thin air with dreadnoughts and battleships numbering quadruple of the cruisers I was fielding. This wasn't the massive fleet that spawned in the defense node either, this was just a random spawned fleet while travelling in enemy territory. 

Fleets would just magically appear, and I'm not talking about the ones that are visible on the map.  Those were quite easy to fight.  No, the random stuff is broken and unbalanced, forcing me to lower the game difficulty to easy so the random spawns wouldn't be as ridiculously overpowered and randomly join a node capture or fleet battle.  However, this made my game too easy and when I got the Titan class Prosperity ship, I was a one man fleet regardless of difficulty.  

This is a major complaint of mine with this title.  There is no explanation why there are random spawns of ships fighting literally every time I make a T-jump or fly around some random point of interest.  This ruins immersion, as I am struggling to build up my fleet, yet ships magically spawn in ridiculous quantities everywhere in the system.

Sending your AI fleets into combat alone is suicide.  Even if you outnumber the enemy at a control point or battle, your side will take substantial loses, whereas, going yourself is a guaranteed win with no losses of any sort.  Thus, the RTS simulation is also broken, as it takes considerable amounts of time to replace losses, but the AI prints ships with funny money.

The strategy is sub-average, but, there are not a lot of games like this.

What is possible?
You can take over stations, defense nodes, and planets.  Basically, you can control the whole Gemini system if you wanted, but there isn't any point to it other than Steam achievements.  Once you capture a planet or two and own a third of the solar system, the game is boring.  You can build ships in your ship yards and send them out to attack, defend, patrol, etc.

You control fleets in the 2d main map as if you were playing an RTS.  You can fly around with a massive fleet at your back.  You can capture enemy ships, put them in your garage, sell them, scrap them, or steal their fleet designs.  You can fly almost any ship in the game.  These are all good things.

Ship Combat.
The combat in this game is similar to SPG2, but better.  You can fly your ship manually with the full degrees of freedom space offers, thus, you can actually dodge incoming fire with pilot skill.  You can fly just about any ship type in the game, which is a big plus in my book.  Combat is basically flipping on auto-target, avoid getting hit, use power-ups and abilities to kill the baddies, and hope random spawns don't bring in more than you can chew.  It was full of action and fun for a time, but end game is quite boring once you have Titan class ships.  

Ship sounds and weapon graphics are decent, improved over SPG2.  Graphics and audio are better than X4: Foundations.

There are various strategies in how you fly, I chose the cloak path, and I had lots of fun going cloak and surprise attacking enemies in the early game.  Even hunting harder to kill enemies that were way over powered for me, but helpless against my stealth power was fun.

Path finding.
As an X-series player, my anus clinches when I see asteroid fields and I have AI ships following me.  However, the asteroids seem to be circumnavigated by AI and player ship with only the occasional shield deflected doink.  The asteroids actually move when this happens, and to date, none of the ships took damage, and almost always avoid impact and keep moving.  So good job.  

There was only occasional derp out with ships when flying near stations or when they dance around my capital ship and doink off my hull, but the ship eventually calculates a course and breaks out of derp jail.  In this regard, I give the devs a gold star sticker of approval because well known competition has been unable to place in a path finding solution for the last 20 years.

Warlords looks and feels like space battle.  Some wonky behavior from time to time, but

review: Always a spaced out starduster I will buy a space ship sim whenever I can ( i.e. it's on sale ). Starpoint Gemini Warlords is what I could call a solid but standard space simulation. It has similarities to many Like Elite, Star Citizen and the many others of that genre. While it doesn't set itself apart in any unusual fashion it's ease of learning to play and strong universe creation is a huge plus. Graphically it is more than adequate, providing plenty of eye candy and eplodey bits. Should keep me plenty busy waiting for vaccines and sunshine.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981829746', 'num_games_owned': 2567, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 280, 'last_played': 1615739392}
review:
I really wanted to like this game. I can't make it through the start of the main campaign. It promises a lot and it might very well be in there, but I have no interest in actually slogging through the campaign to even bother. 

The voice acting it horrible. I understand low budget small companies can't get good voice actors. But please if your going to do it yourself don;t just read the lines with no carrying what so ever. You can pickup the the lack of caring, you would have been better off letting me read it and apply my own voices that would care. The script itself is just poor.

As everyone has stated the UI is horrible you can rebind, but I feel developers say that so they don't have to bother to DEVELOP a functional UI. It can be a cop out.

Sorry I will no longer support the the developer any further if they make more games. There is no effort to improve their designs at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044657199', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 105, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1615464902}
review:
This game is like a sandbox. But it's rained. Lots. And cats have been taking dumps in the sand, not even bothering to bury it. Hobos have also been using it to shoot up on heroin, with their used needles still scattered all around the place, waiting for you to stab yourself on them as you attempt to build your sand castles.

Runs like hot garbage. Optimization that makes games from '92 look like bonafide GOTY titles. Avoid unless your masochistic tendencies and needs cannot be sated via different means. Could be fun if you make it work. Just expect a control scheme that challenges, and beats, OG PC Dark Souls for the highly-cherished Worst Controls Ever awards.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987588169', 'num_games_owned': 2195, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 5095, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5095, 'last_played': 1614085574}
review:
[h1]Mehr RPG als ein Shooter[/h1]

[h2]Gameplay und Design[/h2]
Das Spielen ist [i] (mein persönliches Empfinden) [/i]mit Tastatur und Maus schneller, komfortabler und in hektischen Situationen, dank der Tastaturbefehle, intuitiver spielbar als mit einem Gamepad.
Man sollte sich auf jeden Fall ein paar Tasten für schnelle Aktionen verinnerlichen. Zum Beispiel [b]"C" zum Einsammeln von Trümmern[/b] und [b]"F" zum Auswählen des automatischen Beschusses[/b] von Gegnern in nächster Nähe. [b]"R" für die Auswahl des nächstgelegenen Gegners[/b] ist auch sehr zu empfehlen, sowie die Standardtaste [b]"M" für die Übersichtskarte[/b]. Meiner Meinung nach die wichtigsten Tastaturbefehle, die man wissen sollte.
Das [u]Kontextmenü[/u], welches über die mittlere Maustaste ausgewählt wird, ist sehr innovativ und man hat es sehr schnell verinnerlicht. Hier empfiehlt es sich, dass man im Optionsmenü einstellt, dass das Spiel im Kontextmenü pausiert.
Je nach Auswahl der "Spezialfähigkeit" hat man auch die Möglichkeit diese mit einer Taste zu aktivieren. Meine Empfehlung hierfür ist, dass man es auf die Maustaste für "Browser zurück" legt, da man sich dadurch wieder eine Taste weniger an der Tastatur merken muss und es zusätzlich viel einfacher handzuhaben ist.
Die Größe des spielbaren Universums geht in Ordnung und ist durch DLCs ein wenig erweiterbar.
Die Schiffe lassen sich farblich sehr detailliert anpassen. Die [u]Upgrademöglichkeiten, Forschung und der Skill- sowie Techtree[/u] sind großzügig gestaltet.
Dass auch der [u]Steam Workshop[/u] für dieses Spiel verfügbar ist, ist meiner Meinung nach auf jeden Fall ein großer Pluspunkt.
Da das Spiel mehr auf das Leveln des Schiffes, der Station, Forschung und die Ausbreitung im Spieleruniversum basiert, ist es eher in die Kategorie [u]RPG[/u] zu legen. Dennoch sind auch die Gefechte mit sehr viel Action und taktischem Denken verbunden. Meiner Meinung nach ein sehr gelungener Mix.

[h2]Grafik[/h2]
Auf der grafischen Seite sollte man nicht zu viel erwarten, aber es ist schön anzusehen. Die Anforderungen sind dementsprechend auch nicht wirklich hoch und dadurch ist es auch auf vielen Mittelklasse-Notebooks mit guten Einstellungen locker zu bewältigen.
Dennoch gibt es hier und da manchmal Aussetzer, die mal gerne eine Sekunde dauern können. Jedoch beeinträchtigen diese in keinem Fall das Spielgeschehen.

[h2]Sound[/h2]
Es klingt alles sehr stimmig, allerdings habe ich manchmal in einem Gefecht Aussetzer des Sounds für meine eigens abgefeuerten Schüsse.
Die Vertonung ist leider komplett in englisch und wird mit deutschen Untertiteln übersetzt. Manchmal passt aber der angezeigte NPC nicht zur vertonten Stimme. Ist dann etwas seltsam, wenn eine männliche Stimme ertönt, aber das Bild eines weiblichen NPCs erscheint :-)

[h2]Story[/h2]
Die Story ist gut um ins Spiel reinzufinden und die Steuerung kennenzulernen. Außerdem ist sie natürlich für die meisten Errungenschaften erforderlich. Allerdings habe ich schnell die Story hinter mir gelassen und einen zweiten Speicherstand im Sandboxmodus gestartet. Hier hat man eben komplette Handlungsfreiheit und kann sich seine Welt so schaffen, wie man sie haben möchte.

[h2]Fazit[/h2]
Ein wirklich fesselndes Spiel, sobald man reingefunden hat. Das Leveln des Schiffs und der ganzen anderen Dinge fördert den Langzeitspaß.
Die veranschlagten 31,99€ für das Spiel alleine, ohne DLCs finde ich jedoch viel zu heftig und man sollte hier auf einen Sale warten.

[h2]Tipps[/h2]
[list]
[*]unbedingt mit Tastatur und Maus spielen
[*]die oben beschriebenen 4 essentiell wichtigen Tastaturkürzel verinnerlichen
[*]In den Optionen festlegen, dass im Kontextmenü (mittlere Maustaste) das Spiel pausiert wird
[*]Kurz vorm Erreichen eines Missionsziels kurz speichern. Spart die Reisezeit nach einem schlechten Ausgang der Schlacht. Autospeichern geschieht jeweils automatisch beim Betreten einer Station.
[*]Die "Spezialwaffe" auf die Maustaste für "Browser zurück" legen. Erleichtert den Kampf enorm, da man die Spezialwaffe sehr oft abfeuert.
[*]Auf einen Sale warten :-)[/list]

Danke fürs Lesen und viel Spaß,
McRay

author: {'steamid': '76561198008618422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 2091, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1657, 'last_played': 1613824432}
review:
Duft-o-vision Teilnehmer sollten jetzt den Nasenschlauch anlegen.

- Deutsch wird schlechter später gesehen wurde.
- Ruckelt unter Win10 wenn man Audiodatei 14 nicht ersetzt, egal welchen Supercomputer man verwendet da fehlerhaft codiert. Darauf muss man erst mal kommen, denn zuerst testet man sich ja zugrunde welche mod es vielleicht verursachen könnte dass die fps heftig bei Kampfstart einbrechen obwohl sonst alles butterweich stabil läuft. 
- Macht aber dennoch sehr viel Freude, vor allem da einen die Stories sehr viel Freiheiten lassen sich auf der Karte auszutoben. Kein Schlauchzwang.
- Viel Ähnlichkeit zu Freelancer, aber keine Cantina :(
- Gute mods im Workshop, zB. Star Trek und Star Wars die immer noch super laufen, teilweise sogar gemeinsam.
- Dauert viel pewpew bevor langweilig.
- Im Gegensatz zu X4 hat man hier eben wenn man möchte non stop action, kann auch handeln, Schiffe und Flotten befehligen bei weniger Frust. Nur eben modulare Stationen selbst bauen und 59 Minuten jede Stunde alles über eine 8 farbige Kartenansicht regeln wie in X geht eben nicht :-D

review: Super cool game.  I have played a wide variety of space games and loved SPG 1 and 2.  This game is a great upgrade from Privateer 2 genre.  Space battles through multitude of ship classes from gunboat to dreadnaught.   Trading, piracy, boarding, RPG skill progression, wide array of skills, perks, equipment, enhancements and variety of game-play potentials.  Quest line is basically the tutorial with Free roam and multiplayer options that are very robust.  Recommended for anyone that likes a smooth mix of strategy and FPS space shooter arcade action.

Kauft euch die zusatz inhalte dadurch schaltet Ihr neue Fraktionen frei die Ihr vorher nicht Spielen bin ich der meinung als ich die Inhalte nicht hatte konnte ich immer nur eine Fraktion spielen LOHNT sich auf jeden fall GRINS :-3

author: {'steamid': '76561199013405679', 'num_games_owned': 132, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1469, 'last_played': 1683771738}
review:
Fun game with a unique blend of RPG/4X. Of course this means neither is very deep. Best aspect is the roleplaying. If the progression (going from lone captain -> galactic diplomat and/or conqueror) and gameplay loop (open world space combat/trading/mining) are enough to intrigue you, absolutely worth it. If you haven't tried something like this before, I'd also recommend it. It's really accessible for people who aren't familiar with the genre of either space sim RPGs or 4X games.

However, if you're looking for vastly deep mechanics, or an engaging story, or an innovative twist on either 4X or RPG games individually, I'd say look elsewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038120228', 'num_games_owned': 1219, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1611336288}
review:
STARPOİNT GEMİNİ WARLORDS HAKKINDA
Starpoint Gemini Warlords, rol yapma ve strateji unsurlarıyla birleştirilmiş bir uzay simülasyonudur. Güçlü savaş filolarınızı savaşa gönderin ya da onlara liderlik edin. Seçim senin. Savaş Lordu olun!


Savaş yeteneklerinizi göstermek için doğrudan geminizi kontrol edin. Siz benzersiz becerileri uygularken elle nişan alın ve ateş edin veya topçularınıza işi sizin için yapmalarını emredin. Savaşta sizi takip edecek yoldaşlarınızı seçin ve fazladan yardıma ihtiyacınız varsa, filonuzun görkemli savaşta size katılmasını sağlayın. Warlords'taki savaşlar, düellolardan ve küçük çatışmalardan gezegen yörüngelerinde bulunan devasa filoların çatışmalarına kadar değişebilir.


Gemini inşa edin ve güçlü savaş filolarınızı Gemini'nin diğer savaş çığırtkan gruplarına karşı savurmak için toplayın, ancak onları gönderdiğiniz duruma dikkat edin. Görünüşte zayıf olan bir filoya savaşta kendi lehlerine yön verebilecek savaşçılar, iyi eğitimli uzmanlar eşlik edebilir, ancak korkmayın, filonuzun sizi takip etmesini sağlayarak onları zafere götürebilirsiniz!


Daha gelişmiş silahlar ve geliştirmeler üretmek için karargahınızı ek modüllerle yükseltin, istasyon boyutundaki Proxima'ya giden yeni gemiler geliştirin, yeni yapıların kilidini açın ve tüm bölgenizi etkileyen çeşitli bonusları etkinleştirin. Halkınızın liderisiniz ve güçlü bir lider bir kaleyi hak ediyor.


Bölgenizi genişleterek nüfuzunuzu genişletin ve kaynaklarınızı artırın, ancak savunmanızı çok zayıflatmayın yoksa düşmanlarınız bundan faydalanabilir. Bölge, çeşitli kaynak ve savunma yapıları inşa edilerek güçlendirilebilir ve iyileştirilebilir. Filolarınızın sürekli büyüyen imparatorluğunuzda daha hızlı seyahat etmesini sağlamak için T-Gate ağını genişletin. Zamanında varış büyük bir fark yaratabilir.


Maceranıza küçük, çevik bir savaş gemisinde başlayın ve çok sayıda avcı kanadı konuşlandırabilen devasa bir taşıyıcı sınıfına doğru ilerleyin. Seçtiğiniz imha gemisini çok sayıda silah ve donanımla yükseltin. Ve hepsini bitirmek için, her zaman istediğiniz mükemmel kabı elde etmek için üzerine bir kat boya atın.
ANA ÖZELLİKLER:
Savaş filonuzla yüzleşmeye hazır, 60'ın üzerinde farklı gruptan oluşan devasa oyun dünyası.
Sefer modu - Sol sisteminin uzaylı istilasından kurtulduktan sonra Gemini'nin eteklerindeki çorak Phaeneros gezegenine yerleşen "sürgünlerin" hikayesini oynayın.
Farklı başlangıç kurulumuna sahip beş serbest dolaşım senaryosu.
Savaş gemileri ve korvetlerden büyük taşıyıcılara kadar yaklaşık 90 farklı gemi arasından seçim yapın.
Ekonomik ve askeri gücünüzü artırmak için kendi kişisel karargahınızı kurun.
Prosedürel olarak oluşturulan serbest işler, yükseltmeleri geminize pompalamak için kullanabileceğiniz Kredi kazanmak için harika bir yol sunar.
Prosedürel olarak oluşturulmuş karşılaşmalar, en azından beklediğiniz anda üzerinize gelebilir.
Üç benzersiz karakter sınıfından birini seçin veya kendi melez sınıfınızı hazırlayın.
Kendi geminizden küresel nesneler şemasına kadar her şeyi etkileyen çok sayıda farklı teknoloji üzerinde araştırma yapın.
Solari Concord'un ihtişamı için gemiler inşa edin, savaş filoları oluşturun ve onları her yöne gönderin.
Kaynak toplamayı iyileştirmek ve hakimiyetinizi güçlendirmek için yıldız sistemi genelinde altyapı oluşturun ve yükseltin.
İhtiyaç duyduğunuz desteği elde etmek için diplomatik ilişkiler kurun ve ticaret anlaşmaları imzalayın.
Selefi Starpoint Gemini 2'yi büyük ölçüde aşan mod desteği.

Daha fazla bilgi için, Gamepedia'daki resmi Starpoint Gemini Wiki'ye bakın .
Desteklenen Diller : İngilizce , Almanca , Basitleştirilmiş Çince , Fransızca , Rusça , Lehçe , Japonca

author: {'steamid': '76561198052251167', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 2559, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1612241723}
review:
It is EXACTLY the same game as starpoint Gemini 2, with a new skin.

Exactly the same game, dont bother if you have gemini 2, its a big let down playing the same game.

The only thing the programmers did was increase the amount of ships you can have with you, ouch that piece of programming must of been really intense. All the game play loops are the same except you now cant find blueprints, you have to research them so they made the game easier basically. 

One thing I found funny was the game has an entire tree dedicated to you capturing ships...hint. Then in the videos of showing off the game you send ships off to different fights... er no, thats not what happens in the game, you get a capital ship restriction of 5 ships.... for almost the whole game, and because you want to capture ships, you keep them with you and move as 1 fleet, T-Drive jumping around. As I said exactly the same as gemini 2...

Same gemini 2 but easier.... what a joke.


Its also crashes sometimes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979931562', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 2079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2079, 'last_played': 1587238103}
review: Having had a great time with Starpoint Gemini 2, I expected this to be more of the same good stuff. While the graphically impressive and satisfying ship-to-ship combat remains, the story is lackluster at best and you eventually end up in a perpetual grind for more territories, which quickly becomes routine and boring. At some point the sense of progression and  challenge was lost, and that's when I stopped playing, as there was no story left to sustain my interest. There is a lot of unrealized potential here and I might still give one of the later games in the series a try to see if the developer learned anything from this failure, but there's no way I can recommend this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198353967163', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3795, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2808, 'last_played': 1611097159}
review: Warlords is a nice evolution from Gemini 2 with its resource collection, research, fleet control, politics and conquest. It feels like a more complete and well rounded game, where anyone who enjoys a space/combat game can focus on their preferred way of making progress. Graphics are decent to good and battles are beautiful to behold with all the beams, missiles and fighters flying around. Overall I'd give it an 8 out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198321191848', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2405, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1270, 'last_played': 1633098358}

author: {'steamid': '76561198097243946', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 4118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4118, 'last_played': 1610138847}
review:
I like space opera genre and I like the predecessor of this game (Starpoint Gemini 2), but Warlords is just poor attempt at 4x strategy. When you unlock some endgame ship (dreadnought or carrier) you will be familiar with everything this game has to offer and you will realise that there's just nothing left to keep you playing. The game lacks depth and is just too easy and repetitive (no matter the difficulty setting). 

Stupid AI, boring story line with annoying characters, technical issues, lack of basic features that you will expect from a strategy game. For example diplomacy is just barebones, almost non existent; you can declare war or offer a trade deal. That's it. No proper diplomacy window accessible from map, only some reputation window under some other nonsensical window in menu. 

I like how the game looks (original ships designs, stations, nebulae), I like some game mechanics (capturing ships), but it's just not enough. I also realise this is indie developer project, but again, it's simply not enough.

4/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197970479670', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 2135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2126, 'last_played': 1610245999}
review:
Starpoint Gemini Warlords is one of those games that gets by through an unmet niche.  Some people desire more than a 4X game: they want an open world RPG with the world simulation of a 4X game. I'm one of them. Through the labor of love of the developers, this game made that happen.  However, it is far from perfect or ideal.

As with any game, the first thing I encountered was the GUI.  Their widescreen mode just stretched everything horizontally, defeating the point, so I played in a window.  Consolitus has partially ruined the interface: there were only two "fire" buttons, tied to shooting off every light or heavy turret on your ship.  There are two banks of four choices for your abilities and one-shot equipment. That limitation saddens me; an MMORPG-style hotbar would have given players many more options. The chassis description page was a bit of a mess, all tucked away in the "Geminipedia," sometimes with duplicate entries or no entry at all.  Why was that never fixed?  Probably because the GUI was a gigantic undertaking.

The problems are more than skin deep, invading the gameplay itself.  Some features are missing, such as the unique chassis buffs from the original Starpoint Gemini.  The ranks of ship chassis reflect mere power rankings, lacking meaningful roles to serve (except for freighters and some Titans).  The "light" and "heavy" hardpoints are sorely inadequate for outfitting a wide variety of ship chassis.  Most of the hotbar-activated equipment is doomed to become obsolete through progression.  I played a Marauder with a "cloak" ability that was effectively a "get out of battle free" card that I could play every 8 seconds.

The trading mechanics are surprisingly incomplete.  You can get unlimited amounts of any commodity by simply redocking, so why limit those amounts?  Lucrative trades can repeat forever because there is no simulation of supply and demand.  I effectively broke the credit economy when I discovered one, as there is no mid-flight interdiction, not even enforcement on moving illegal goods.  They sure put an awful lot of work into the sprites for a trading system they could not fully implement in the end.

I was most bothered whenever Starpoint Gemini: Warlords showed itself to be more of a 4X game pretender than a real one.  That was the feature I came for, but the treatment here is very rudimentary.  You can build a fleet of ships and have them attack other fleets, but their relevance feels undermined by clouds of (possibly hugely overpowered) ships spawning spontaneously.  It would have been nice to assign civilian fleets to the work you see needs doing (like you can in Avorion) rather than just the imaginary work that spawns on the map.  Instead, their role is to bolster a secondary economy just for the faux-4X side of the game.  Like most games where battles can occur without the player, combat that transpires without the player's presence has drastically different outcomes.

Despite these problems, I still played through the entire first campaign of Starpoint Gemini: Warlords, which took me over 30 hours.  I ground my way up from the humblest of tiny Gunships to a mighty (and aptly-named) Titan, doing three kinds of content along the way: story missions, freelance missions, and the spontaneous happenings on the map.  I suppose it was ultimately the tight core loop that kept me playing; there is a strongly-reinforced reward cycle here that keeps the game chugging along, flaws and all.

Should I recommend this game?  Not for just anyone, no.  Enthralled by those tight core loops, I cannot truthfully claim that I did not lose my time playing this game.  But, as I said, this is a game that attempts to fill a niche sorely in need of filling.  I can forgive where it falls short and hope they do better next time.  

X4: Foundations and Avorion probably did a better job at simulating things deeper than Starpoint Gemini Warlords.  But they are also janky for their reasons, so pick your poison, I guess.  Maybe one day we'll get that perfect economic space simulation RPG, but this is just another one on the path to finding it, and you can decide for yourself if you want to go along for the ride.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041117767', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 8560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2889, 'last_played': 1680194938}
review:
It's not a perfect game. It can become repetitive easily. There are oddities with the english translation and some campaign mission logs are cut off.
I love the hell out of this game. It is so much fun seizing territory and building towards the next opportunity. I not only get to take some pirate's home, i can take his ship in a boarding action and scrap it to build my newest carrier.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006025643', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 7, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1609028780}
review:
I was looking forward to giving this a go but it wasn't possible as the game has buggy controller detection (which you can't turn off) which meant I couldn't navigate any of the settings menus. The only suggestion when searching seemed to be unplug all your devices that may be picked up as controllers, nobodies got time for that as I've got a HOTAS plugged in. Sort the game detection out and let us disable controller support.

Maybe if you either A: intend to play the game with a controller (I'd suggest a legit xbox controller otherwise mileage will vary)  b: you don't have anything that may be picked up as a controller or c: you don't mind rummaging around and unplugging everything every time you play it, maybe then it's a good game?

author: {'steamid': '76561198044378097', 'num_games_owned': 620, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 987, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 987, 'last_played': 1607275673}
review:
[h1]TL:DR[/h1]
"not the best of both worlds" would be a good summary of this game.
The game is fine in the space travelling/battles and a ok '4x'.
it doesn't add up really well and it feels like both of the element were created completely separately. The game is a grindfest.

[h1]Full details[/h1]
[h2]Story[/h2]
This game is played by first selecting a scenario that dictates how you start the game. there is also a campagn that is only available from the campagn scenario. 
[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
As said in the TL:DR, the game is based on a 2 layer gameplay.
[h3]Space[/h3]
You are able to drive ships from various class, gunship, frigates, carrier... Though they kinda feels the same, the difference in combat is crystal clear, the game really make the small ships irrevelant after a short while. You will get to upgrade rather fast if you farm money efficiently. 

To farm it, you can either do freelance mission, comming with a nice variety of objective, delivery, assault on base, convoy attack, defence... The thing with these mission is that the objective only appear if you have selected the mission, meaning that attacking a structure will spawn the structure only if you selected the mission. Meaning that have to go personnaly take the mission and fight WHILE you can move fleet around to mess with other faction. would be neat if the fleets could also do mission to grind money.

You can either farm it through trades, which feels kinda weird. You can farm hundreds of millions in a few dozen of minutes ingame but your faction is basically useless, in term of income.

The travelling part is fine because you get t-drive charges early on in the shop that can teleport your fleet around.

[h3]hub management[/h3]
You are the commander of a faction. You have a faction HQ, that will be upgradable with new module that will enable perks, researchs, fleet size...
This management resolve around 3 ressources, minerals from mining, gaz from extracter and material from recycling.
The mineral are mainly used to upgrade the hub, the gaz is used for researchs and the material to construct ships. 
There are building in the map that will make weekly deposit of the ressource they produce and you can also farm a bit yourself to get started.

The starchart, will inform you about the different faction and the outpost, that are capturable to expand you territory. 
With the fleet you produces in your base, you can go and conquer the map by taking outpost/ station/planets. you can have a fleet to follow you to help yyou in combat. 

The flaws of this management part are numerous: 
-There are no advantage in going to war, the ressources production rate of building are laughable, and diplomacy is reduce to having a perk named "diplomacy". 
-There are basically no interaction with the other faction. You can only have 2 trade treaty at a time, and they bring ressources or a bonus for X week. You can have a faction "work for you" if you grind their reputation to max but its another bonus or free sheit. there are no "let's be ally to destroy X" or disruption  to slow X down. just grind on grind. 
-the ressources are way to scarce. I don't mean that the game should allow you to build a planetary assaulting fleet in a week but i mean more than a gunship per week in one of the major faction would be cool.
-You have to farm everything yourself, it really don't feel like you are at the top of a faction.

[h2]Visual and sound design[/h2]
The sound of the differents weapons is really good, and the combat chatter/ voice in general is very well made. 

[h1]Why i/ i don't recommend[/h1]
The game in itself is ok-ish. The thing is, it's a 4X where you will have to farm for everythin. a small ship is 500 material, you get 500 mat per ingame week, money is way to scarce for a commander that rule over a faction. I had to do cargo runs to earn the money to make upgrades/buy ships. I couldn't bring myself to grind for the proxima researchs and didn't finished the campagn. 

The game is bugged from the start. An setting option makes the game unable to launch... after 30min of playing around of trouble shooting, i found the solution in a forum post from 2017... a bug still around 3 years later... other than that, alt+tab while t-drive, and boom, the game is stuck in a unending loop. The game got game breaking bugs.

Last reason, this review is heavily bias because i played starsector recently and it was a better mix of 4x / space ship battle than this... The game is 15$ on their website which make it more expensive if you buy spgw on sale, but it's imo worth way more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198257983854', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 958, 'last_played': 1607199962}
review: Juego bastante simple, las mecanicas no son super dificieles como otros juegos de getion espacial. Al principio puede paraecer mucha informacion, pero se aprende rapido y despues es simplemente ir repitiendo acciones. Esto ultimo es un punto en contra porque te puede terminar resultando un juego monotono y repetitivo. Lo que puede salvar esto es el workshop de Steam, aunque mucho no se utiliza. Salvo por esto, es juego tiene mecanicas dinámicas, buenas historias y graficos desentes. Lo recomiendo para los que les gustan los juegos de gestión espacial y no tienen mucho tiempo para sentarse a aprender a jugarlos, en un dia o dos ya se aprende a jugar y despues se puede dedicarle un par de horas cada tanto para avanzar.

review:
Game UI is quite unfriendly, if it weren't for the YouTube tutorials, I wouldn't know shit how to control the bloody thing. The worst part are the frustrating controls. They work like absolute shit, it's almost impossible to control it with a mouse. I cannot even minimize the game, because it won't work properly, so you have to restart the entire game. Which makes me unable to search for stuff on the internet.
Campaign story didn't pull me into it enough to make me not refund the game.
Looks like I will still have to wait for a proper tactical capital ship space sim. This one is a waste of money.

review: Said, to hell with it, it's on sale, why not try it. Crashed in the first 10 minutes of playing. Hmm. Okay, try again, reloaded into the latest save... Bugged... Can't continue the story... Okay, reload the first of two saves i have, an autosave... Loaded, continued, same crash, same location, selecting my first ship. Damnit. Third time's the charm. Get past the first ship selection and continue on my merry way. Third actual mission in the game... Crash on jump to location... Mmk i'm done. Three crashes in 65 minutes of playing the game. No thanks, do not recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021054774', 'num_games_owned': 87, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1183, 'last_played': 1709532694}
review:
Love this game.

Exactly what I wanted. I missed playing the old Klingon Academy and was looking forward to another space navy-type game with the ability to capture ships. This builds upon that in a Mound and Blade style where the captured ships build into a larger game.

This game has some bugs, but the community is really good in the discussion sections to work through any gameplay issues. FPS bug in battle and broken lightening flash issue was my main problems. But, there are solutions in the discussion.

Would highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065933797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 520, 'last_played': 1700479682}
review:
8 hours into it and I find that all the things I did in the first game are a chore in this version.
 
 Missiles lock forever.
same 5-6 enemies everywhere (no variance in spawns)
boarding ships sucks even worse
universe feels less alive so far
best way to make money so far is to break open randomly generated boxes sigh Like the game community hasn't had enough of breaking loot boxes (these aren't ptw boxes)
Camera has always had a slow wonky feel even in the first one.

positives
stuff is prettier
beginning story was cool enough
customizing ship color and such is kewl 
it seems to have more strategy there though I haven't got to it in 8 hours.  I have been flying around just exploring a good portion.

I have great respect for the peoples that made the first game but I can't say i'm really enjoying it after 8 hours.  Really kind of bummed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198132995625', 'num_games_owned': 1414, 'num_reviews': 754, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 712, 'last_played': 1578558012}
review:
Starpoint Gemini Warlords
4X SciFi von 2017.
900. Spiel mit Bewertung.

Beginne dein Abenteuer mit einem kleinen und wendigen Kampfschiff und erarbeite dir den Weg zu einem riesigen Trägerschiff mit zahlreichen Kampfjägern. Verbessere dein eigenes Schiff mit einer Vielzahl von Waffen und Erweiterungen. Am Ende verpasst du deinem Schiff einen neuen Anstrich, um das Schiff zu besitzen, das du schon immer haben wolltest.

Starpoint Gemini Warlords ist eine Weltraumsimulation mit Rollenspiel und Strategieelementen. Konstruiere und schicke deine mächtige Kriegsflotte in den Kampf, oder führe sie selbst an. Die Entscheidung obliegt dir. Werde zum Warlord!

Dies ist der Werbung entnommen und beinhaltet sowohl die positivste aber auch die negative Seite des Spiels.
Ich habe Teil 2 dieser Serie sehr gelobt, aber irgendwie will der Funke bei dieser Version nicht überspringen. Dieses Spiel bietet viel mehr als Teil 2 insbesondere da ich alle DLCs habe. Aber irgendwie macht es mir keinen Spaß. Ich kann gar nicht so genau sagen was mich eigentlich stört und warum es mich langweilt.

Entstanden ist Warlords in Zusammenarbeit mit der Steam Community um Teil 2 weiter zu entwickeln. Meiner Ansicht nach liegt genau dort mein gefühlsmäßiges Problem mit dem Spiel, ich erkenne keine klare Linie, es ist von allem etwas und noch viel mehr.
Somit ist für jeden was dabei, wer damit klar kommt ist hier richtig.

In diesem Spiel gibt es zwei unterschiedliche wichtige Aufgaben zu übernehmen. Zum einen dein Schiff auf zu werten, dies benötigt Geld das du mit Aufträgen verdienst. Sowie dein Heimatreich, dort werden Erz, Gas und weiteres Material benötigt um Expandieren zu können, was du mit Handel generierst. Die Forschung ist der wichtigste Aufgabenbereich um den du dich kümmern mußt, dicht gefolgt von deiner Basisstation. Natürlich gibt es noch mehr das du machen solltest.  

Es ist eine gelungene Kombination aus third person Weltraumgefechte mit 4X Strategie und Rollenspielelementen, die in einem sehr großen Weltallgebiet angesiedelt ist.
Außer deiner gibt es noch über 60 Weitere Zivilisation und jede Menge zu entdecken. Obwohl es mir nicht so gefällt empfehle ich es dennoch, insbesondere für Neueinsteiger in die Welt von 4X Weltraum Games. Für Leute die viel Zeit und Lust haben, empfohlen.

Starpoint Gemini Warlords
4X SciFi from 2017.
900th game with evaluation.

Begin your adventure with a small and agile combat ship and work your way to a huge carrier ship with numerous fighters. Upgrade your own ship with a variety of weapons and enhancements. In the end, you will paint your ship with a new coat of paint to own the ship you've always wanted.

Starpoint Gemini Warlords is a space simulation with role play and strategy elements. Construct and send your mighty war fleet into battle, or lead it yourself. The decision is yours. Become a warlord!

This is taken from advertising and includes both the most positive and negative side of the game.
I highly praised Part 2 of this series, but somehow the spark doesn't want to jump over to this version. This game offers a lot more than Part 2, especially since I have all the DLCs. But somehow I don't enjoy it. I can't say exactly what actually bothers me and why I'm bored.

Warlords was created in cooperation with the Steam Community to further develop Part 2. In my opinion, that's where my emotional problem with the game lies, I don't see a clear line, it's a bit of everything and a lot more.
So there is something for everyone, who can handle it is right here.

In this game there are two different important tasks to take on. On the one hand, to upgrade your ship, this requires money that you earn with orders. As well as your home empire, ore, gas and other material are needed there to be able to expand what you generate with trade. Research is the most important part of your job, followed closely by your base station. Of course there is more that you should do.

It is a successful combination of third person space battles with 4X strategy and role-playing game elements, which is set in a very large space area.
Besides yours there are over 60 other civilizations and lots to discover. Although I don't like it that much, I recommend it, especially for newcomers to the world of 4X space games. Recommended for people who have a lot of time and inclination.

author: {'steamid': '76561198320108981', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 4345, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4278, 'last_played': 1689782432}
review:
Game has nearly half as much grind as doing a mobile game free to play.
Game also has a lot of bugs, some would be game breaking if reloading did not fix them.
ive had enemy ships infinatly spawn creating infinate combat (which is not supposed to happen)
ive had trouble merging fleets (onto me) so they can help me
ive had bugs with the coms image from a voice over comms message getting stuck to a default portrait. (hard to tell who was talking)

Game is also quite unbalanced, with its grind, its encoutners etc. and dosent make much sense too with its fleets.
random enouters spawned more ships than their actual military sometimes, the weird Y shape enounter was one of them. had one with all high end ships too, i think.

I have completed the main story. i had to do the same exact missions over and over again so many times just to get money to get a high end ship, and high end weapons. as i leveled up they just stared to create ridiculous encounters with other high end ships even for the smallest of things. i had an army of high end ships and i dont think i could have made a profit from the fleet assault missions. having to grind killing multiple high end ships was not fun.

was a grind to complete the campign too.
not much content, very repetative game. had to grind freelance missions for tons of money to do stuff and level up too.
unlocked most content and still had trouble with campign and games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061081487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 3075, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3075, 'last_played': 1549778816}
review: A seriously flawed game bloated with redundant and unintuitive systems. There are classes, skills, techs, items, equipment, ships, cultures, commanders, quests, factions, random encounters, trading, etc. The combat is overall somewhat repetitive and lacking depth, but fun. I would still recommend the game for fans of the Mount and Blade hybrid strategy model. But not for $30.

review: "Мы не можем потерять он".  " Рад видеть тебя на ногах, командир. Хоть на миг мы подумали, что мы потеряли вас. Мы не были уверены , что вы успели с Икара......." Успели что ? Я пытался понять сюжет, но даже в столь ущербно простом сюжете, понять мысль с таким переводом не реально. Нужно открыть новую игровую выставку Г3, главный стенд для вас.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156221725', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1596, 'last_played': 1601404328}
review:
I played Starpoint Gemini 2 for years and for a space sim game it was very in depth in its story and political strife as factions come into play as you fly through the galaxy upgrading and becoming a player. 
Warlords does not disappoint and is very much much like its previous game a very in depth game. But this time you get a base of your own to defend, Build as you conquer other areas and play political games while flying through space commanding other ships. You even get to give civilian ships goals to assist with gathering resources toward the goals of Concord. 
This game will have you wondering where the time went as you explore a rich galaxy full of fun game loops. The campaign is fun and engaging. Skills mean something in this game and i am enjoying it. 

Thank you Little Green Men and cant wait for the Starpoint Gemini 3 Release. Great job!

[list]

author: {'steamid': '76561197996022419', 'num_games_owned': 296, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 220, 'last_played': 1599984853}
review:
I tried and tried and tried again... the dev's promised over and over that they would try and fix the controls and camera settings but even after 3 years nothing.

The story is interesting, the galaxy is great and looks nice but the controls and camera settings destroy the entire gameplay, you end up spinning around your ship senselessly without any feeling of what you are doing, where you are going or who you are attacking, rarely had games that almost made me vomit... a pity really, but cannot recommend this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023709494', 'num_games_owned': 648, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2148, 'last_played': 1604781468}
review:
Gameplay: 6/10
Story: 7/10
Graphics: 8/10
Performance: 6/10

Overall: 7/10

Starpoint Gemini Warlords (SPGW), like it's predecessor, Starpoint Gemini 2 (SPG2) is an arcade space combat and trading sim where you command large capital ships as opposed to smaller fighter craft. But unlike SPG2, SPGW has a 4x-lite twist where you conquer territories across the map, build fleets, manage resources and engage in diplomacy with the other factions. Sounds like an awesome idea, right? And you'd be correct. It's a great idea! But I think a disclaimer needs to be mentioned before proceeding with purchasing this game. I really need to highlight the "4x-LITE" bit. I've observed that a lot of people have purchased this game going into the same expectation as X3's own strategy mechanics, which are very deep and evolving. Some people have even bought SPGW thinking that it's something like single-player EVE. 

The 4x strategy in SPGW is extremely lite. You have 3 basic resources consisting of ore, gas and materials. Ore can be mined from asteroids, gas can be mined from gas pockets and materials can be scavenged from derelicts. You can either collect these resources manually or send out "civilian fleets" to collect it for you. Civilian fleets are invisible and you can't actually see them, nor can you see other faction's fleets and success is chance based depending on how many defenses you have in an area. In addition to that, you can use civilian fleets to trade resources with other factions depending on what you have a surplus in once you unlock the necessary component to do so. Allied factions will also gift you resources occasionally. In addition to those resources, you also have credits which can be gained through radiant missions, trading or capturing and selling starships. Lastly, you have a fleet cap number and cap on larger capital ships. All of this is dependent on the amount of territory and planets you possess. As far as mechanics go, it's very basic. The AI doesn't seem to be under the same rules as the player as far as I've noticed. For example, there is no way for the player to cut the AI off from resources or hinder their resource production in anyway except by claiming territory and while the AI can attack the player, they rarely seem to do so. At least as far as I've determined in the campaign mode. This doesn't make it a bad game though! But don't buy it and go into playing it thinking that it's a very deep level of strategy and space combat, otherwise you will be very disappointed. 

Compared to the previous SPG2, SPGW has also streamlined many of the space combat and trading mechanics. For example, trading is now static and prices on goods never change. The economy is no longer dynamic and it is very easy to become extremely wealthy long before the end-game. Smuggling also seems to be broken as illegal goods do exist in the game, but I've yet to have factions scan my cargo and do anything about my "illegal goods", even when I'm traveling around in a massive battleship that is impossible to not see on the sensors. But the biggest issue is that credits aren't important as they were in the previous title, being limited to only helping the player and procuring trade deals with various factions. It would be nice if credits could be used to complement a player's fleet, using credits to purchase the services of mercenaries like the previous game. Aside from this, combat is still much the same, although equipment is a lot easier to come by. 

As far as graphics are concerned, I would definitely rate them significantly better than SPG2. Starships do have a sense of scale now and you can seriously tell the difference between a small little gunship and a massive carrier. Planets and space stations now have actual 3D visuals and you are greeted to a nice little cutscene when landing on them, which is much better than the 2D artwork rendering (which while nice, felt hastily put together). The story is also a lot better compared to the previous game where I felt lost half way through the story. The game includes an encyclopedia if you wish to immerse yourself in the lore. 

Overall, I would definitely say that I enjoyed SPGW, but I'd say that I enjoyed SPG2 more. The previous title had a good balance between complexity and arcade features. The dynamic economy, smuggling, the fact that each ship held a role from the smallest corvettes that could out maneuver capital ships to cruisers with cloaking devices and carriers that sacrificed firepower for fighter/bomber wings. SPGW stream-lined A LOT and the lite-4x mechanics don't really make up for everything that was lost from the previous game. Does that make SPGW a bad game? Absolutely not. I still recommend it, but I do wish that SPGW was more of an extension of SPG2, rather than a new stream-lined game to the SPG series.

author: {'steamid': '76561198868378774', 'num_games_owned': 298, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 68, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 68, 'last_played': 1599016298}
review:
很遗憾地说，我并不推荐这部游戏。
优点：还算精美的画面。丰富的剧情和较为充实的游戏内容，好看的飞船，以及能开大飞船
但其缺陷也十分明显，那就是莫名其妙的背景画面和极为糟糕的操作系统。我为什么喜欢太空游戏。因为里面有各种挑战想象力的场景和飞船，能让我畅想人类未来的可能性。我希望能在这部游戏中找回当年玩homeworld和玩FL的感觉，但首先在这游戏中，尽管有着好看和丰富的飞船，但其视角并不能自如的转动只能固定在后方，看飞船屁股。拜托，这是飞船不是妹子，看屁股什么的很糟心。可能其实是有办法的，但我摸索了一个小时左右也是白给。其次，宇宙的背景只是繁星满满的贴图，星星还贼亮，违和感简直爆表。其三，战斗系统也是莫名其妙，既不是FL那样的狗斗，也不是勇闯银河系那样的操作大飞船战斗，反倒是用自动开火看电脑打，你只需调整飞船角度来让火力最大化就行了。这么一来，战斗就毫无技术性和趣味性可言。一个小时下来只觉得身心俱疲。其实还有许多槽点，但我也实在了解不深。
总之，如果你不是太空游戏的狂热爱好者的话，否则不推荐

author: {'steamid': '76561198007664837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 25406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6622, 'last_played': 1601960293}
review:
Good game if you're into the space/freelancer thing.

As with all the Gemini games I've played, there is a learning curve.

Fleet management could be better. Particularly with the player's fleet.

The customization/paint system could be better, but it could also be worse. It's not powerful enough for *my* standard of paint job quality,(I'm a wargame miniature painter) but it's powerful for the constraints of the game system. I'd like to see a better masking/selection system, and the huge paintbrush icon sometimes gets in the way of what I'm trying to do. Just give me a dot. LOL. But that could just be me being nit-picky. Better lighting and zooming features would also be a plus. However I should note the lighting *does* change with location. Planets and the home station seem to have the best light.

But, once you get past those things. It's a good solid space empire/fleet management game. Definitely worth playing, if you're a fan of the genre. If you're not, you'd probably find yourself frustrated and confused with this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001914453', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 1060, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1060, 'last_played': 1596255092}
review:
This game that will demand a lot of your time and patience. So much so, I feel it crosses from enjoyable to drudgery as you scrounge for every last credit. This game involves HOURS grinding away doing freelance missions, mining, bounty hunting, scavenging, and occasionally just flying around in search of loot. While this has some very enjoyable aspects to it, the sheer amount of time to go from flying a garbage scowl to a respectable ship may be too much for the casual player.

The graphics, while stunning in the previews, are never really showcased. You follow behind your craft from a respectable distance that never allows you see the detail. Your expensive turrets are little sticks on your wings, heavy weapons when shot are glowing orbs, and your fighters buzz around as shapeless sprites -- you never see the detail. It is the same when landing at a planet, you treated to a short cut-screen, but there is no life to the worlds you visit or the characters you interact with. 

The combat takes a bit getting used to as you are not a fighter pilot, but instead are commanding a capital ship with semi-autonomous turrets. Your role is too steer the ship while the turrets fire, occasionally launching heavy weapons, and deploying your special skills when needed. There is a certain enjoyment to the fleet aspect of the game, with you very slowly building a massive armada to follow you around as you scrounge for money, occasionally engaging in epic battles with other fleets. But a serious flaw to this system is that lower level ships become obsolete, with no advantages and only costing you hard-won resources as they are blasted out of the sky in minutes.  

The story is okay. Each step in the campaign has you getting enough credits for a new ship, completing a mission, and then meeting the requirements for the next. I never finished the game, reaching a point when the next step would involve over 100 million credits to complete the requirements -- most missions paid 500k to a million per run. This is a good example of the grindy nature of the game. 

This game has some fun parts, but they are overshadowed by the sheer amount of time that must be committed to fully enjoy the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075351784', 'num_games_owned': 1004, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 4961, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1675965504}
review:
[買ったもの]
これの旧作の無料配布で興味を持ち日本語入りだったので購入しましたっぱ(｡･Θ･｡)

[良い点]
-日本語である
-日本語マニュアル付き
このページにある「マニュアルを見る」のリンクからたどると日本語のpdfファイルがある

小一時間試しに遊んだ感じとしては
マニュアルを読まずにストーリーモードで操作を覚えようとしても厳しいと感じた
[悪い点]
Nvidia環境であればまったく問題なく遊べるようです
Radeon環境の場合何故か相性がでる場合があるようです
（何の問題も無い場合もある）
ウィークリープレイの時にタイトルメニューの先の
「ニューゲーム」をおした先を30分程操作し動作が問題ないか確認してから購入しましょう
ぇ？確認しないで遊ぶと…はまったorz　自分のような事になります(ﾉΘ`)

[運悪くハマった場合]
単純に初回起動時前に⚙→ディスプレイ→グラフィック設定→クラシックアプリ→ゲームのexeを選択→グラフィックアダプタを指定
それから起動でも改善するらしい
AMD+Nvidia環境でもはまることがあるらしいが
https://steamcommunity.com/app/419480/discussions/8/1620599015888414046/
starpointwarlordsconfiguration.cfg
SwitchToBestAdapter項目で書き換えて調整すればなおる事もあるらしい


いずれにせよインストールフォルダーにログファイルが出力されるのでそれを見て必要に応じて調整する事

('Θ`)ｳｰﾝ　　雰囲気はよいんだけどねぇ…

[ここまでプレイ1時間経過後ぐらいに書いたもの]

[47時間経過後]
[良い点]
-司令部建設して内政しつつ艦隊を建造して運用できる
-運用して作った艦隊をプレイヤー艦隊に追従できる！
（大艦隊を引き連れて遊びたい方にはとても良い）
-上記の操作ができることにより艦船操作が下手くそでも内政力からの物量で押せる（かも）
-日本語化は９割五分違和感無い

[悪い点]
-大型の艦船に乗り換えるとノーマルビューだとしんどい
（船の縮尺に問題があるように感じる/VボタンやTABキーで切り替えは可）
-ドッグでトレードボタンおしたつもりが背景表示になる
（ESCキーでもどせるが…）
-メインキャンペーンで装備品の付け替えの強要＆高い装備付け替えで飛ぶ恐れ
（乗り換え強制系で消える時と乗り換えでガレージ保管の場合がある）
-複数枚グラボがある環境やAPU環境との相性がある気配
-敵船を選択してターゲットロックしないと発動しない
(Rキーで最寄りの敵艦船選択してやればまあいいとして)
-セーブデータをロードすると装備品が全ロストする事がある( *･Θ･).*;'.､ﾌﾞｯ
これ一部のキャンペーンのせいなんだろうか？と思われる節がある
セーブデータがキャンペーンの12から15のどっかのタイミングでおかしくなるような…
-手動での砲撃で敵の艦船を狙っても小型船相手だとかなり無理がある
（Fキーで自動砲撃するそして船の角度を全てのタレットから狙いやすいように調整する事に徹すればいいが…）

[プレイ開始から60時間経過]
セーブデータの破損にも挫けずキャンペーンをTheEndさせたっぱ(*´-Θ-)-３
うーん…遊べるは遊べるがフルプライスはやめておいたほうがいいセール中にどうぞ(*p'Θ'q)…

( 'Θ`)ｳｰﾝ　セーブデータがおかしくなる件はどうにかならんものか
最後までやってゲームの図鑑（ペディア機能もある）見ると一部化けてるところがあった
案外キャンペーンじゃなくてフリープレイでやったほうが変な挙動に見舞われないかもしれない

[プレイ開始から70時間経過]]
うん　キャンペーンじゃない方だと特にこれといって
セーブデータがおかしくならない(*´-Θ-)ﾎｯ-３

[プレイ開始から80時間位経過]
真面目に全エリア制圧しようと思うと可能だろうけども流石にマンネリ化してくる面が…
この辺りは他にできることが増える面が乏しいのでちょっと他の積みゲーに移動するかのぅ
（セーブデータ台無しでのやり直しが祟っただけでそれが無ければ無難な所）

author: {'steamid': '76561198002312713', 'num_games_owned': 634, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2615, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2612, 'last_played': 1595664308}
review:
I don’t remember how this game got into my wish list, but when it went on sale I decided to buy the whole “collection”.
The game is an ok 7/10 game (I only played the main campaign and titans DLC). It will give you some good time, but nothing too great.
At first it gave me some Freelancer vibes (and I LOVE Freelancer), but only a very limited ones. It soon became apparent that this game is very different. There is nowhere near the same exploration element to the game. Yeah you can get some things and small bonuses but not like in Freelancer where all the most powerful stuff was hidden. 
Bigger ships are locked behind leveling system. Most of the game balance is centered on leveling system. The higher your level gets the tougher your enemies get. However weapons are not locked in the same manner. So if you manage to get enough money you can install absolutely any gun including most powerful ones from the start. 
Which gets me to the issue.
In this game trade is OP as hell. To get to a new level you typically need to complete several tasks (like 3-5 in the beginning). Or in just one run from starting station to starting planet and back (provided you use freighter) you will already get yourself enough XP to level up. And that is just a downward spiral. Trade makes so much XP that in 10 minutes you will already be able to buy yourself a battleship. If you choose to continue to get enough money to buy a freightliner (a much bigger freighter essentially) then you will be lvl30 (which unlocks all possible ships in the game). With freightliner you will already be able to easily make tens of millions of credits per run. I guess the developers tried to limit the trade by limiting the amount of goods available for purchase but they messed something up because you can instantly restock the goods by simply taking off and landing again (you literally have to press only 2 buttons for goods to reappear: ESC and Alt). You can’t restock consumables like shield boost this way, but you can restock the goods.
So in a matter of less than an hour you can make enough XP and money to buy yourself one of the best ships and fit it with top of the line weapons. And then for most of the fights you can just go AFK for a minute while your ship just wrecks the hell out of enemy fleets. And also you will have enough money to just buy out all other stations in the galaxy which makes some storyline elements kind of silly when you “hack” communications of your own station or have to do some work for the corporation you already own to get the data you need.
That is kind of sad because this game has some good mechanics when it comes to combat and boarding enemy ships. Trying to manage your shields and weapons energy is engaging at first, but at higher levels it just becomes useless as pretty much nothing would be able to deal noticeable damage to even penetrate your shields. And sadly this makes the game boring at the higher levels as it is just fly in and wait for your guns to finish off another swarm of enemies who has no hope of dealing damage to you.
I had only encountered bugs two times. Once when in the main storyline where I needed to beat a faction which I already wiped from the galaxy the game didn’t allow me to proceed, but a reload from previous mission fixed that. Another one is about Titans DLC when you need to conquer territories in a somewhat different way but I figured out that it was more about upgrading your garrisons and grinding down the enemy ones in fights rather than a regular capturing of the garrisons.
Overall I had some good time with the game, maybe different campaigns will make the game more engaging.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042374625', 'num_games_owned': 240, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1199, 'last_played': 1596085565}
review:
A unique game in its own right, and very similar to the original [url=store.steampowered.com/app/290300/Rebel_Galaxy] Rebel Galaxy [/url], [url=store.steampowered.com/app/252470/Space_Pirates_And_Zombies_2] SPAZ 2 [/url], and [url=store.steampowered.com/app/48700/Mount__Blade_Warband] Mount & Blade: Warband [/url]. 
[h1] Story: [/h1]
Don't go buying this game if you're looking for any kind of story. Although I'm sure the developers put a little bit of time into it hoping it would be something special, it feels generic and convoluted, and serves its only purpose to facilitate learning game mechanics. 

[h1] Gameplay: [/h1]

Realtime strategy mixed with a space RPG. On the surface, you can upgrade your ship and its weapons, and change it cosmetically. The controls, which is what most negative reviews spawn from, actually work perfectly for the game, just take a little while to get used to. The actual flying and RPG elements are supposed to be mostly click and mouse based anyway. 

Deeper in, and taking a look at the map, and the ball is in your court to retrieve resources for your faction and conquer territory, make peace or war with factions, build up armies, and explore.

[h1] TLDR: [/h1]

Game is incredibly unique and worth a play. Solid real time strategy and RPG.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128505537', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 7951, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4807, 'last_played': 1707042710}
review:
好的方面：
舰船模型还不许错。
风景好。

不好方面：
剧情
前期被敌人暴打，后期以一个人带一群进队打一群敌人，且模式重复度太高，后期大多时间都是在攻占区块，极度无聊且重复。
另外不少的剧情关卡就只会刷敌对船只，大量航母，bug也是多的一批，剧情要求攻占据点，但过去打了完了居然不算占领？？？
泰坦级船只太过垃圾除了血多、盾高毫无用处，且bug还多，突然进入亚光且停不下来，速度比正常的亚光还快很多，穿越整个地图估计30s足够了。
在比邻星旁边，进入bug亚光，比邻星会消失，且不会刷新召唤的异常点，bug出的概率非常高。
攻占敌方星球只能用比邻星，在充能期间也是极度无聊，只会一直刷船，平时穷的一批的星球到了这个时候，无畏舰成堆的刷。
中文翻译
感觉像是半机翻，部分字体对音不对字，还有部分是英文没翻译，更差劲的是研究里的改装武器，同一个武器，研究目录一个名字，介绍一个名字，商店里卖又是一个名字。。。。。。

author: {'steamid': '76561198093624480', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 10838, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10198, 'last_played': 1630493099}
review: НА ЛЮБИТЕЛЯ. Рекомендовать широкой массе не могу, несмотря на то, что я наиграл немало времени-шанс что вы такой же отбитый как я невелик). Даже не могу сказать чем она меня зацепила. Больше похожа на игру для телефона. И будет чувство небольшой халтурки буквально во всем, ну может звуковое сопровождение не огорчит. Мне сильнее не понравилось отсутствие более подробной инфы кораблей, оружия(в т.ч. истребителей в ангаре), оборудования и умений.  А перевод реально через словарь или онлайн переводчик.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026966205', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 5438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5423, 'last_played': 1594595467}
review:
Disclaimer: I didn't play through the story, I only played sandbox mode.  So I have no comments on the story.

Ok, so, Starpoint Gemini 2 is like freelancer, where you go around and the focus is on your single ship.  I bought it during the summer sale, and it was great, however I got to endgame and realized you couldn't capture stations or planets, which left me wanting more.  So, I looked into the next game in the series which was Warlords.  I realized I could do everything I wanted in this game, while still being able to deck out my ship and customize everything.

I started playing in sandbox mode, roleplaying as the Emperor of Mankind, the goal being to conquer every last bit of the gemini system.  It was a bit confusing at first, but once I got the hang of the game, dear god did it deliver.  It was great till I reached my fleet power limit, and I realized there was a cap on the number of ships you could have.  That was not the experience I wanted.  I wanted to build MASSIVE fleets and just absolutely destroy everything.  Thankfully, this game has a lot of mods.  One of the mods upped the fleet cap to 3 million, which was exactly what I wanted.  I installed the mod and began building my fleets.  I started declaring war, and taking over system by system by system.  It was incredibly satisfying to purge Gemini of all lesser factions, and impose the will of the Emperor on everyone.  

The second issue was that ships are limited by your "rank" (level), so again I installed another mod to remove that cap, and started buying the best ships I could afford.  When you buy ships, you can paint them (like in a paint program, not like a button that says "paint").  So eventually I got a Titan ship at around level 45, painted it gold, and stamped it with an empire decal.  It was an absolute beast, and after I decked it out with the best weapons and upgrades I could find, it could take over stations all by itself, with my personal fleet there mostly just to clean up any ships trying to run from the battle.  Again, this was very satisfying.

As of today, I just captured the last regions in space, and completed the game.  During my final conquests, I had "Calorus Rex" by Sabaton playing and it was glorious.  The Imperium of Mankind is complete, and there are none that can threaten the Emperor of Mankind.  

The Emperor Protects.

My final rating is, 8/10.  Great game, had tons of fun.  I recommend checking out the mod workshop and installing the mods to increase the fleet power cap, and ship rank requirements.  That way you're truly allowed to do whatever you want provided you have enough resources.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037516864', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 1547, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1594265765}
review:
This game has lots of potential but it is severely hamstrung by a rudimentary combat AI that pretty much either only sits there (large ships) or only tries to get on your tail (small ships).  The result is that both you and the AI mostly only fly in circles.

"Dog-fighting" is pointless because the AI weapons NEVER MISS from what i see.  Light weapons, whether fired by the enemy or fired by your own crew with "fire at will" toggled on, always seem to converge on the target regardless of maneuvering, and heavy weapons track unerringly unless you use a decoy or a jump to sub-light to evade them.  This makes combat both formulaic and boring.

NONE of the light ships are properly configured for this kind of combat.  Nearly ALL of their weaponry is mounted on the "top" of their hulls like a ground-pounding tank extracted from a world war 2 simulator where combat pretty much only takes place on a 2-D plane.
That is not appropriate for an inherently 3-D combat environment.

If maneuvering imparted ANY chance of dodging weapons fire then a forward configuration on light ships makes sense, but ONLY for those ships intended to launch fast attack runs on larger targets where you dodge enemy fire, dump a load of ordinance, and then burn-the-hello-out of there to set up for another attack run.

That is not what is happening here.  

Going fast in combat provides no material benefit whatsoever and only serves to complicate the task of keeping your top mounted weapons facing the target.  Just go slow and keep your top-front towards the enemy and that's pretty much it.

Next, the writing and story-telling of the various missions are just about the MOST predictable writing i have ever seen in a space game.  Every mission i have run i called out what was going to happen and so far i have yet to be wrong once.  

THEN there is this one main story mission where you get tractor-locked by a battleship and its escorts and you have to survive about 60 seconds before rescue.  I watched my corvette's Hull-points vaporize in less than twelve seconds, but instead of exploding my ship was repeatedly given free auto-heals.  It literally could not die.  

That is some SERIOUSLY lame story telling.  If the writers are going to railroad me like that they could AT LEAST do me the courtesy of giving it to me in a cut-scene.

The Territory control aspect of the game is an interesting thing to pair with the simulator part, but on its own it stands fairly below average for a 4X strategy game.  

I do like how controlling your "empire" doesn't take a great deal of effort so it doesn't detract from the flight portions at all.

All-in-all, while this game has lots of potential and they blended the sim with the 4X well enough, it's not a good space sim or a good 4X strategy.  Like "Spore", Starpoint Gemini Warlords tries to be too many things at once and it spreads itself too thin to actually excel at anything.

The only thing that impresses me is that the game manages to not suck despite spreading itself too far to actually be good.

If you are looking for reasonably challenging or engaging space combat though then go find an old copy of "Freespace".

If you are looking for good story telling and great dialogue then find an old copy of "Tachyon: The Fringe".  Bruce Campbell really KILLS IT as Pilot Jake Logan.

Try "Stellaris" for a fantastic 4X game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025863296', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1701, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1701, 'last_played': 1593922665}
review:
I suppose this is... a decent enough game.  I picked this up because a few people said "it's like Kenshi in space".  I'm about 28 hours in at the time of review and I have to say I'm not seeing it.    I've worked through the story missions and it's turned me loose to build and conquer as I please and as I expand my territory more and more I am getting the feeling like I've already seen everything the game has to offer and I'm just going to see more of the same going forward, except flying a bigger ship, and with more ships following me, firing stronger versions of the same wearpons I've had since the beginning of the game.

The tech tree is fairly shallow (maybe at most 3 levels deep in any category) and doesn't unlock anything particularly new for the most part, it just makes the existing things "a little better".  

The space flight and combat is fairly simple.  That's probably a good thing, because you probably lack the satisfying control scheme to fly your ship well enough to take on anything more complex than what it offers you.  It will interest you at first but quickly become a pattern of setting your weapons to fire at will and just sit back and wait for combat to be done.

Game content comes in the form of taking it upon yourself to fly around and attack various installations, or the same varity of freelancer jobs that repeat, or the same variety of 'random' encounters that pop up on your radar, all of which there seems to be at most 5 types of encounters in any of the categories.  You can build, but only in the handfull of pre-determined locations. 

Despite being a space game, the universe is mostly 2D with a little room to fly up and down the z-axis.

if you are itching for a space game and are still interested in giving this a try, grab it on an 80% sale and see if you like it.    I'm not saying it's bad, I'm just asserting that there are plenty of others that will satisfy what you're looking for WAY better, depending on what you're looking to get out of it. Stellaris,  Elite Dangerous.. Homeworld.. X3/X4... FTL...

review: Decent game but has a few inconvenient flaws that hold it back.  The hud/ui is garbage, shields regen agonizingly slow even outside combat/with boosted regen and don't scale to weapon strength at all, enemies spam heavy weapons, and the ship boarding is neat but clunky to use.  Also has very few mods and, the ones they do have, don't fix any of the flaws.   I'd give it a 6/10, wait for a sale and dont pay more than $15ish for it AND all the dlc combined.

author: {'steamid': '76561198272129144', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 8742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8742, 'last_played': 1576253182}
review:
多数の要素を含んだスペースコンバットシム。
キャンペーンはお使いと戦闘が基本となり所々で拠点の強化を挟んだりとゲーム内の要素に触れる感じ。
ストーリーの流れに沿って行くだけだとかなり味気ないゲームに感じると思われる。艦船の強化、お金や資源の調達、領地の拡大と維持など自発的に行うようになると楽しい。が、ここはプレイヤーの好みに合わないと難しいと思う。
ストーリーの存在しない自由なモードも存在するがほとんどは初動にちょっと差があるだけであまり変わらない。ただ全勢力が敵対しているモードは物凄く楽しかった。
以下細かい所のレビュー。

【戦闘】
アクション性は低く、前後左右のシールド強度を保ちつつ攻撃していくのが基本でそこに主人公の3種の職業にあわせたスキルを使うくらい。
後半に入るまではパワーゲーム感が強いが最大クラスのドレッドノートまたは戦闘母艦を手に入れると大分熱いバトルが発生するようになる。
僚艦は弾避けのカカシくらいのものだが賞金首や大戦力相手には結構役立つこともある。

【戦艦】
種類はかなりの数があり、デザインも多様性がある。性能差はクラスごとに大きな差があるので自分のレベルと財布の許す限り上位のクラスの艦を購入していくことになる。
ただ艦の販売場所は星系内にかなり散らばっておりどこで何が売っているかの案内もないので方々を駆け回って探すしかない。自勢力の艦も悪くはないがほとんどは同クラス内でも性能は高くなくデザインもクセの強いものが多いのでゲームを楽しみたいなら好みの艦を探す旅にでることをオススメする。

【領地争奪戦】
正直これに手を出さないとこのゲームは面白くないと思う。
星系マップ内に惑星・ステーション・前線基地・生産設備などがありそれぞれに所有している勢力がある。敵対勢力が居るのであれば直接行って叩き出して占有でき、友好勢力が居るのであれば宣戦布告の上叩き出して占有できる。
占有したポイントそれぞれのメリット(資源の入手や独自の効果など)があり、ポイントが多ければ多いほど資金・資源が面白いほど入ってくるようになる。
当然敵も奪い返しにくるのでこれに対抗する訳だが自艦だけでは手が足りないので資源から味方艦を生産し防衛に回したり直接侵攻させたりして領地を増やし、入手した資源でまた艦を生産し防衛侵攻拡大…と加速度的に忙しくなってきてとても楽しい。

【交易】
自勢力または友好勢力と交易品を売買できるのだが、価格は固定なので何も考えず売り買いして飛び回るだけで儲けられる。輸送艦を運用することで効率を上げることもできる。
交易では資金だけでなく経験値も得られるので交易だけでドレッドノート購入までいくことも可能。商人プレイしたい人向けの要素であると思われる。

【その他いろいろ】
グラフィックはきれいで宇宙を旅している感はでている。発着場まわりだけだが惑星それぞれの様子を見ることもできる。
ストーリーは淡白に感じるがメニューにあるテキストから背景を知ることができ、かなり作り込まれた世界であることが分かる。他のスターポイントジェミニシリーズは未プレイだがその辺りも関わっているのかもしれない。
