author: {'steamid': '76561198017946533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 5213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4205, 'last_played': 1520106130}
review: Upon revisit after the dev's request, there's is just nothing keeping me here. I've played the game for over 80 hours and i have no intention of playing a game with frustrating combat. I understand that this game is going for a capital ship style battle system, but after playing Starpoint Gemini 2 for so long its a hard adjustment to make. I continue to consistently target enemies that are out of range despite practically ramming them with my ship. No other space combat game i have played has had weapons with such short ranges. I dislike the clausterphobic battles and would rather play their other game Starship Gemini 2 as a result.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017565554', 'num_games_owned': 1296, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 515, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 515, 'last_played': 1497099758}
review:
Vyhozené peníze...

Zmatené ovládání, nezábavné souboje, plochý příběh který vás vůbec nevtáhne, dialogy pouze s textem a ikonkami mluvících jako v nějaké adventuře z roku 2000. K tomu všemu nudná RPG stránka která vám vůbec nedává pocítit, že jste na dalším levelu. Všechny lodě (co jsem stihl vyzkoušet) lítají stejně a nemáte tak pocit, že se někam posouváte když si koupíte novou. Docela vtipně také zastavují na milimetru když stáhnete rychlost na 0, což při letu vesmírem působí vážně autenticky a neruší to prožitek (IRONY). Grafická stránka průměrná což ovšem nebrání tomu, aby mi hra hnala grafiku na plné pecky (Radeon RX 480). 

Strategická stránka hry celkem ujde a může být asi v pozdějších fázích hry i zábavná, opět zde ovšem chybí chuť stavět a zkoumat nové moduly či technologie, kromě většího přijmu surovin totiž opět nemáte pocit že by se vaše "Impérium" někam posunulo.

Nevím, na co jsou fanoušci SG zvyklí (toto je moje první setkání s tímto universem) ale SGW působí jako nedodělaná 10 let stará hra. Opravdu jsem si přál, aby mě bavila a spoustu lidí podle recenzí kolem nejspíš i baví, takže pokud vás láka tak zkuste a uvidíte. Neudělejte ale stejnou chybu jako já a kupte si ji přímo na Steamu ať můžete přinejhorším využít možnost refundace. Já bych to teď rozhodně udělal, kdybych mohl...

author: {'steamid': '76561198030872772', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 6629, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4070, 'last_played': 1500216770}
review:
Mein Ersteindruck.
Ich habe noch keine Mission gespielt oder mich bewegt,sondern nur etwas in dem Handbuch (vom Spielstartmenue aus geöffnet) gelesen,und die Steuerung versucht zu konfigurieren (bin Linkshänder) und es sind schon knapp 70 Minuten Spielzeit verbucht.Das schmälert die Zeit zum Ersten Eindruck mit der Option auf 120 min Rückgaberecht doch ordentlich.
Meinen X-Box 360 Controler konnte Ich nicht konfigurieren.Womit Ich an die Tastatur und Maus gebunden bin,was mir eher nicht passt.
Ich möchte in einem Raumschiffspiel mit dem linken Analogstick das Schiff neigen können und mit dem rechten Analogstick  rollen. Back soll für vorheriger Feind sein und Start für nächster Feind. Button A soll Gas geben und Button X soll für das Bremsen sein. Button Y für Raketen und Button B für Feuern. Mit den 4 Schultertasten möchte man das Schiff nach links,oben,rechts und unten bewegen lassen können. Dann bleiben noch 6 weitere Optionen am Controler zu vergeben..mit L3 und R3 (indem man den Stick drückt)  und am Steuerkreuz.
Von diesen Möglichkeiten ist das Spielso weit weg,daß Ich schon über eine Rückgabe nachdenke.

Spielen kann,bzw möchte Ich im Moment nicht,weil mich zum einen die Vielfalt der Tastenbelegungen etwas überfordert und zum anderen kann Ich im Fenstermodus,das Fenster nicht verschieben bzw. positionieren. Stattdessen verändert sich die Rahmengröße in der Senkrechten,wenn Ich oben "Greifen" und versetzen möchte.

Also kann Ich nur noch etwas abwarten,ob sich per Patch etwas tut oder zusehen,das Ich das Spiel in den nächsten Tagen vor Ablauf der 2 Wochen Frist,zurückgebe..und das ohne echten Eindruck bekommen zu haben..mal abgesehen von einigen Youtube Viedeos..wo jemanden die Steuerung auch nicht so recht in den Kram passen wollte.

Als Ich in den Diskussionen gelesen habe,was schönes finden zu können,was das Spiel zu einfach macht,fand Ich das als Notlösungsmittel gut.Soweit Ich das verstanden habe,wurde das jetzt schnell geändert..finde Ich auch schade.

Auf jeden Fall kann Ich so keinen positiven Ersteindruck vergeben.

Nachtrag:Der X-Box 360 Controler funktioniert jetzt in vollen Umfang,ohne das Ich Veränderungen vornehmen mußte.
Um das Fenster im Fenstermodus verschieben zu können,gehe Ich oben im Rahmen auf Vollbild und dann greife Ich ich den Rahmen,woraufhin er wieder in die gewählte Fenstermodusauflösung swicht.
Ich gebe dem Spiel meine Empfehlung.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033023216', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 479, 'last_played': 1497057868}
review:
I had this game explained to me like a simplified version of X3 or Elite Dangerous.  Along the same line, you build up a fortune, all to buy a bigger ship, all to build up a fortune, to buy a bigger ship, and so on.  You build up a fleet alongside that can help on missions, and nice as they are I have issues with current implementation, but we'll get to that.  As a comparison to X3, the controls and menus are simpler to navigate, as is the map, perhaps to the point of being detrimental.  
I would then contend the game is a simplified version of SPAZ (which lets face it, is a pretty simple game).

Compliments:
Looks nice
It's a space sim, so bonus points from me there.
The controls, menus, and map are easy to understand.  
You can play as a tactical fighter or a large commander sitting in the back.

Complaints 
"Trading" is essentially a dump.  You gather things on your travels, and then sell all because there's no worth to them beyond that.  Where you sell them doesn't really matter.  
Fleet mechanics feel incomplete.  Using different resources, you can build up a fleet which follows you into combat.  Problem is the ships are expensive and weak.  The only options to upgrade their capabilities essentially jumps the cost into being competitive with the next class of ship.  Even should you develop a hoard to follow you, they can all get wiped out in a single mission rated green "easy level".  I had one mission to destroy a solar array.  Took in a fleet strength of 2400, myself in a frigate.  My frigate destroyed majority of defenses, meanwhile four other frigates, two corvettes, and a couple gunships are wiped out by only four other platforms.  All platforms dead, I then sat for ten minutes firing my weapons at the solar array while browsing the web.  Nothing else to do really, the thing just had ridiculous amounts of health.  So yeah, balancing needs some work.

Fleets are restricted to combat support.  I can build an armada, but they can't help me with things like mining, salvaging, or even hauling junk.  With a merchant perk, you can sell your ships your junk, but that just makes the mechanic feel even more defective.  This is strictly a combat focused game, with a flavor of resource management.  By management, I mean the real world feeling of there's never enough.

Ship designs are tactically lacking.  They look nice and handle... well they handle like spinning a stick on ice, but they move around.  Problem comes from weapons layout.  Even frigate class ships have all light weapons on front, heavies on back, and firing is restricted to sight angles.  So you face an enemy to take down their sheilds, and then wiggle your butt at them to fire a single missle.  Specifically a small 30 degree section of your butt.  Recommendation for devs is to have multiple types of each ship level, some for the... interesting weapon layouts, and then others which are actually useful.  

As you increase in ship size, not much changes.  The ship got bigger, can take a bigger hit, and hold more weapons, but layouts are the same as are capabilities.  As such continued play value goes in the crapper fairly quickly.  

Space is quite vast.  So vast that perhaps the jump capability should be a recharge rather than a purchase?  Pay 100k+ for a handful of jumps, which really are only enough to get you back to the single starting quest depot, for jobs that pay about 100k.  First couple hours are just schlepping back and forth.  

There are plenty of quest types to try, but the game is such a grind that I quickly focused on kill target or deliver goods.  They pay about the same, take a fraction of the time, and lower chance of wiping my fleet than other missions.  Random missions pop up throughout the map, but most are a slog in the mud.  Scan this debris field, scan these anomalies, run around to find a lost ship, etc.  

Finally the story.  I began on the freelance mode at a friends recommendation.  After conquering seven territories and losing my fleet to a green mission, the grind sunk in and I thought "Hey, maybe a story line would help tie this all together and break through the monotony".  AVOID THE STORY!  I made it as far as character creation before terminating.    The characters are sporadically voiced, and the four men at the start sound like they're all voiced by the same guy.  I have no problem reusing voice actors, but it can't be that obvious.  I couldn't help but imagine a grown man playing with dolls voicing their trip to the store.  
The sequence also fails to draw the player in.  Spoiler alert (for all the tutorial stage is worth), you follow a prototype ship out that starts to fall apart just from floating in space, only to have it be destroyed by sabatoge and the big bad enemies.  As the commander of that ship, you are held responsible, but given another chance.  By another chance, you are reduced to a rank and file captain in a gunship forced to pay your own way to glory.  Hell of a chance guys.  

TL:DR:  
The game is a grind fest in space.  It lacks the depth and replayability of more complex games, as well as the short term interest of more customizable games.  Fleet mechanics are a big draw, "Build mighty war fleets and send them into battle or lead them into combat yourself", but fleets are weak, AIs won't focus, and the mechanic feels incomplete if not broken.  Resource management is a slow trickle, no risk/reward sensation.  No sense of progression.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080141647', 'num_games_owned': 160, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 2473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2300, 'last_played': 1526053175}
review:
I'll start off by saying this game needs work. Yes, it's released, but that does't mean it's at a "released" level. It starts off great with impressive visuals, voice acting, and a great big open world. But less than an hour in, the voice acting stops, the flair has worn off, and the grind has set in. 

The greatest problem with this game is grinding. There are many different tasks you can perform on the ship and there is also a 4x element in the mid to late game. The problem is how reiterative the grinding is. Each mission category is completely the same mission over and over. Trading is boreing, there is no dynamic economy, mining is slow and unrewarding, and boarding is the lamest qte i've even seen. On top of that, there is no reason to explore the great big world they offer here. The main story begs you to head to your next objective as fast as possible. Sometimes if you don't go there fast enough, you just lose. No notification or anything. You just lose...

The 4X element is poor. Diplomacy is laughably bad, its too easy to take an enemy base, sign a peace treaty, and take another base, and immediately sign another treaty. Youre in the corner of the map and surrounded by pirates in the early game but they never attack you. They only defend themselves and try to take back what you took from them. Fighting stations is cool, but repetitive. There are so many of them and each battle is too similar. The AI is not good and easy to manipulate. Late game is just putting down the mouse for five hours and coming back disappointed that the world state is the exact same, only you now have a few thousand more ore. The ressource accumulation is also unbalanced. Upgrades take multiple real time hours to pay themselves off and are ridiculusly underpowered. End game is just a wall of ressource requirements. It's not fun at all to me, personally. I finished the main quest and just quit the game. 

Why am I being so negative? Because I enjoyed the game. Space games are a small market with few competitors and unpicky gamers. That does mean I will call a bad space game a good game. This game is... ok. I loved it. If you like space games, you will love this. But it needs work. It's worth the price, but come back in a year and you will enjoy it more when it really is finished.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116363932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 5947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5659, 'last_played': 1547572706}
review:
50 or so hours into the game and after conquering like 1/10th of the map there is nothing more to do then actually finish sweeping over the map.
This game really lacks end game mechanics, the new/bigger ships don't really give you the wow factor a big ass ship like a dreadnought should give. Resources go up pretty fast, my fleet is always maxed out however there is absolutely nothing to do with it. Just an endless grind of conquering stations in a repetitive way. Somehow this game reminds me of Mount & Blade, I really love that game but in my 3000+ hours I actually never ever finished one game due to lack of endgame content. 

After finishing this game (if I can even make myself play that much longer) I will probably never touch it again, just like Starpoint Gemini 2, which was more fun to play because of the story mode.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
UPDATE

So I managed to scrape myself together and start another run. Started over from scratch and even installed 3 DLC's (Titans Return, Deadly dozens & Cycle of Warfare). Another 40 hours into the game.

Deadly Dozen: Sure Deadly Dozen brings you some "cool" stuff by hunting veteran pirat lords. A bounty was set of around 4 million credits, one of the higher bounties you can get for the pirate lords. When I found him it turned out he was flying a destroyer, a destroyer that disintigrated after 3 seconds against my titan. Regular warmaster jobs actually pay more and are most certainly more "difficult". Another thing it adds is being able to aqcuire new ships they seem to fly. It's just not enough!. This DLC is a total rip of. It just added more of the same and they actually made it a payed DLC. It does not adress the issue of late game lack of content.

Titans Return: Felt nice to fly a titan once more. However especially upgraded these things are battlewinners on their own. It's more fun to fly a dreadnought since you will have some sort of a "fight" atleast. The only thing I really loved about it was the story line. It gave me something to do and distracted me from the grind ahead. Yet again, doesn't add to the real flaws in the game.

Cycle of Warfare: Gives you some new scenario's to play. A new alien race, playing as a pirate lord or 3 other human factions. Sure this is great and all but it does require you to start up a different scenario. Meaning if you're like me 53 hours into a game, it requires a restart with a different starting scenario. Let's say it took me 40 hours now to get to the point I am in my latest restart. Maxed out fleet, nothing left to upgrade or research. It will probably take me another 15 hours to steamroll the map. Maybe faster, it's just an estimate. Restart the game with the alien faction and what about that. Another 60 hours of pure grinding ahead of me to finish this "new" game mode. 

This game had so much potential but even after installing 3 DLC's the base game is just broken. I love the game itself, the general concept of it, however it's just a grindfest untill you conquer the entire map. Yet again I find myself grinding it out till the end, an ending I will probably never see. I conquered around 50% of the map and there is absolutely nothing to do. Again my fleet is maxed out, again I have resources I can't spend, again it's the same major flaw.

The sandbox mode is just broken, there is absolutely nothing to do after aprox. 30 hours but grinding it out till the end. The endgame mechanics are non existing. I'm really sad, I gave it another try with DLC's this time. This game needs a story mode to distract from the lack of content. I wouldn't even care if they again added a story line leading to a massive invasion with an epic battle in the end. Really a missed opportunity with so few good space games out there.

review: It improves nearly every aspect of SPG2 while also adding it's own signifigan features and additions. While no single feature as fleshed out as a game in a specific genre that it draws from, it melds them together very well and still has enough depth to keep your intrest. Think Mount&Blade in space with some elements from Freelancer, with the gameplay style of SPG2.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048910194', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 7092, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1570, 'last_played': 1555205454}
review:
Starpoint Gemini Warlords (SPGW) gracefully bridges the gap between the X series and more accessible spacefaring adventures like Freelancer and DarkStar One. While it may lack the maturity and beautiful complexity of X3/TC/AP, and although it occasionally struggles to emulate the personality and charm of Freelancer, the game more than makes up for its shortcomings with an engaging gameplay loop and tons of possibilities for the player to explore.

If you've never played a SPG game before, you will almost certainly have some difficulty getting accustomed to the controls, especially in a firefight. You will be relegated to smaller spacecraft in the beginning, and although they're quick and agile, you will get beaten up a lot. Retreat is an option you should always keep on the table. Once you're at the helm of a capital ship with a solid fleet behind you, though, battles become a more tactical affair. You will be managing firing arcs, power allocation, and damage mitigation on your own ship, while commanding your forces to focus fire, engage, or retreat when a situation demands it. Once you "get it" the combat is extremely satisfying.

Outside of combat, you will be tending to your fleets and various installations from the galaxy map, reinforcing and defending your territory, and sending civilian fleets on missions to (hopefully) obtain resources that are crucial to your expansion. Meanwhile, your science labs will be tasked with researching new technologies to improve your economy, military installations, and your own personal ship's components and weaponry. It's a very cool 4X mash-up that works surprisingly well, even if some of the elements aren't nearly as fleshed out as one might expect from a proper 4X game. 

On the plus side, much of the tedium of actually managing an empire in a 4X game is reduced or eliminated entirely in SPGW, leaving the player free to do whatever he wants whenever he feels like it without feeling like something's going to go horribly wrong back at home while he's out pew-pew'ing at pirates.

The more I play this game, the more I want to play it. Even though the presentation can be a bit underwhelming and dry at times, it's got some mean hooks that keep me interested and engaged. As a fan of the genres it represents, I strongly recommend this game to like-minded gamers without any reservations.

review: I bought this game after playing SPG2 (which i got for free) enjoyed it enough to take a punt on SPG Warlords. I'm sooo glad i did, every element of its predecessor has been improved and the speed of progression and how quickly you can earn money to buy bigger/better ships and guns is much faster than before.Theyve also added station building in so after a few story missions you can build extra hubs which give various bonuses. author: {'steamid': '76561197990917469', 'num_games_owned': 716, 'num_reviews': 106, 'playtime_forever': 1134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1134, 'last_played': 1519173358}
review:
[h1]Lets start with the stuff everyone only cares about:[/h1]
[i]Please remember: This is my own opinion.[/i]
[i]Update: 21.02.2018[/i]

[b][u]Pro:[/u][/b]
[list]
[*]Rather big maps
[*]Good graphics and sound
[*]Dialogueoptions that seem to even influence the story
[*]Once the game opens up, there is a lot of freedom
[*]Plays a bit like a mix of Freelancer, Stellaris and X
[*]Runs relatively well on a 2500k, 8GB Ram and a GTX 980 on 1440p
[*]A lot of things to do
[*]Mod support
[/list]


[b][u]Contra[/u][/b]
[list]
[*]Wonky controls
[*]Framedrops every now and then
[*]Even though it is on an SSD, the environment sometimes takes ages to load
[*]Really stupid AI
[*]Weird, confusing UI and menus
[*]Even though the game looks mostly fine, the graphics are pretty bad at times for no real reason
[*]It is sometimes unclear why something won't work or isn't selectable
[*]Not enough depth in my opinion
[*]Relatively bad tutorial. Many things and activities don't get properly explained
[/list]


[h1]Now about some individual points that bother me and prevent me from fully recommending this game AND feeling good while doing so: [/h1]

[b][u]Graphics and Sound[/u][/b]
The graphics are pretty decent. Nothing bad but also nothing special, but it gets the job done. 
At times especially ships look pretty bad for no real reason. 
I had this sometime happen to me that my own ship looking like it is being rendered at a third of my resolution, while everything else looked just fine. 
I also had completely random FPS drops, sometimes even down into the 30, again for no real reason. A few seconds later it ran just fine again. 

The sound itself is good and i like the OST. It just lacks some sort of "epicness" like other spacegames do.

[b][u]The UI and menus[/u][/b]
I don't know what went wrong here or who the hell thought these are good design decisions but the UI as well as the menus are mostly horrible to use. 
Sure you get used to it after some time, but this shouldn't be necessary. 
At first you will be overwhelmed by it. Some points don't get any proper explaination and are just unclear until you eventually learn it yourself. 

I also don't get it who the hell thought it would be a great idea to have fleet management in the game, but don't show any useful information of your fleets anywhere. 
Be it the map, or your own HUD there is no info about your fleet anywhere. You can't even see which ship is part of your fleet and which one is just the AI security/trader/mining vessels, because they all got the same markers. 
You don't really get to see how much HP your ships have either, unless you target them and try decipher that little display for it. 
This brings me up to the dialogue options, since setting a formation is one of these options. 
To assign your fleet a specific formation, you have to talk to any ship inside of it and select it from there. 
You can NOT do this anywhere on your HUD or from the map. You HAVE to talk to one of your ships. 
Your own fleet, or allied ships in general also make stopping at stations to empty your cargo unnessecary. If you have the Merchant I perk, you can just talk to one of your ships and dump everything you got there. 
Another thing is that it is often times not clear why you can't pick something from the dialogue. If i capture a ship, there are always some options greyed out and you have to guess why you can't pick it. 

There is no real overview for trading with other stations, it seems like you have to guess what they might have in stock and what not. Same goes with their ships and equipment. While your own station always seems to have everything in stock, others do so its mostly guesswork. 

Researching isn't easy either. Most of the time the descriptions are pretty funny but they lack any real stats or description of the thing you want to research. There are a few researchable weapons for example, but you can't see any details about them. Only what type they are. You have to research it and hope that it is any good. 
The UI also doesn't explain any differences to you. Plasma, Shockwave, Railgun, Missiles, Fusion Torpedos? Yeah go and find our yourself what they are and whats different other than the damage and energy requirements. 
You can also buy enhancement that, for example, boost your radiation damage... I have yet to see any weapon that tells me what kind of damage they deal. 

One thing that probably bothers me the most is the overview for buying and equipping ships. For around 6 hours i played thinking that the only shipstats in this game are the Hull and Cargo capacity. Then i randomly found out that you have to hover over each individual slot to see its stats. This wasn't explained and this is inconvenient, Especially since you can't compare multiple ships that you don't own. 
If you want to upgrade to a new class, you have to either memorize the stats or write them down for each ship to find out which one would be the best for you. 

[b]TL;DR:[/b] The game lacks a lot of general information on your own empire, fleets, yourself and the general universe. A lot of the things are hidden somewhere in menus you didn't know existed or are just extremely inconvenient. 


[b][u]The gameplay:[/u][/b]
The controls are a bit weird at first. Unintuitive, but you will get used to it eventually.

To interact with stuff you need to aim with your mouse and click with the middle mouse button to open a menu. 
This is extremely inconvenient, especially during combat. It is slow and sometimes even confusing. You need to pop up that menu and then search what button you wanted to select. 
Why search? Because they move positions depending on how many interactions are available for you. The symbols are also blue on blue, another design choice i don't really understand at all. It might look fancy, but it makes it actually harder to see for the player.

It also seems like you can't tell your fleet to stop firing. They will just obliberate everything in their way. Even if you are fast travelling around, they will stop and shoot any enemy fleet they encounter. Oh and you will encounter an enemy fleet basically every 10 seconds during sublight.

Another thing i dislike is how you can only encounter 3 types of enemies: Traders that ,for some reason, will try to fight you. Miners that, once again, will try to fight you and actual combat ships that will also try to fight you. It doesn't matter how powerful you are or your fleet is, even a single ship will just kamikaze into you. 
Fitting to this are also complaints with the AI. They all just seem to try and hug you to shoot you. Only Warlords seem to have some kind of tactic.
Your own fleet also seems to be extremely stupid. They just won't stop [url=https://gfycat.com/CourteousDimpledIbadanmalimbe]ramming[/url] each other. 
If you select a specific formation, they will try and hold it during normal flight or while they are alone, but in Sublight or T-Drive? Nope they just swarm around like extremely quick and angry bees and keep ramming each other and yourself. 

[b][u]Conclusion:[/u][/b]
The game is great to waste some time, but it has a lot of issues. It is sometimes extremely annoying and i don't think it is worth the 32€ pricetag. If its on sale and you got time to waste, get it. If i had more space, this review would be more extensive.

[b]I visited back now after almost a year and many things are still not fixed. Everything in this review still applies. I also dont like how new, important features are DLC locked.[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198152760885', 'num_games_owned': 17519, 'num_reviews': 481, 'playtime_forever': 748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 691, 'last_played': 1497306327}
review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
I found myself a new favorite space simulation since Freelancer. It’s called Starpoint Gemini Warlords, but I prefer calling it “Space Tycoon 2017”. Sure, between 2003’s Freelancer and present day, there were at least a dozen new complex space simulations being released on Steam or otherwise. Yet those were a bit, out of my league. I would have loved to sink dozens if not hundreds of hours in CCP Games’ EVE Online or Egosoft’s X Series, yet I always felt that those titles required a pilot’s license and a Ph.D. in Economics before I’d fully enjoy them. I’m exaggerating, of course and I hope you can take a joke. Yet Freelancer, that “arcade” game by comparison to the aforementioned ones, had it all. The looks, the sounds, the gameplay and most importantly, the user-friendly interface which endeared it to me.

[h1]Story [/h1]
Starpoint Gemini Warlords is the third title in the eponymous series and I must confess that I never played the previous two as much as I did in Warlords’ case. I’m sure that the larger picture is a direct continuation of the main plot and subplots present in the first two titles but my point is, even if you only purchased and played the game I’m reviewing today, you won’t feel left out. Warlords does a stellar job at providing a lot of reading material and in-game auxiliary videos. The only other video game I remember taking its story and setting to such great lengths in terms of manual complexity, is The Witcher: Enhanced Edition. That is high praise in case you were wondering, since I like reading stuff on almost any topic.

Indeed, you can probably spend about an hour or so, just getting acquainted to Starpoint Gemini’s rich lore. I won’t spoil that for you, but I will refer to Warlords’ protagonist and his crucial role in this game. Like many other gameplay mechanics I will write about below, you can customize your character within this title as well. Male or female, several portraits to choose from and even a multitude of traits/perks to further ensure your own vision and touch. You can’t complain about games which offer you so much freedom right from the start. The prologue has players controlling a future underling of the character you’ll create, since Starpoint Gemini Warlords puts an emphasis on the chain of command and promotion sustained by meritocracy.

You served as an officer aboard a Solari Concord dreadnought prototype which got sabotaged and destroyed during its maiden flight. The plot shall obviously thicken and you’re soon no longer regarded as a suspect or just a henchman. Ironically, you’ll get promoted until you control your faction's entire war effort and your former superiors become your subordinates. Now that’s something Freelancer never even dreamed to achieve. It’s far better to bark orders at others than to follow them through your entire career, right? Solari is your faction and you can interact in a friendly (or less so) manner with several more. As with so many other Sci-Fi settings, a civil war is brewing in Gemini as well. You will have to join in eventually, but you can still keep yourself busy while earning hard currency one way or another. Even an altruistic administrator can play the ruthless smuggler in his spare time. Freedom of choice, baby!

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
Developer Little Green Men Games has made a name of itself with the Starpoint Gemini series also for using and constantly improving their proprietary graphics engine, named “Whale”. So Starpoint Gemini Warlord uses Whale Engine 2.5 and it features both the eye candy and the stability to wholeheartedly enjoy the experience. Playing it in 4K resolution, I would get around 35 frames per second so I settled for 2K res and constant 60fps. The screenshots still look great and there were no frame rate dips or crashes to desktop. As for bugs & glitches, I met some when activating T-Drive (long-distance propulsion) and entering a new area, such as an asteroid field which would load a few seconds after I arrived. And no, that’s not “normal” or acceptable since I play all my games on an SSD. I can imagine that certain asset loading is even longer on an HDD. Hopefully, future game updates can iron out this issue.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The soundtrack in Starpoint Gemini Warlords is pretty much what you’d expect from an excellent simulation. Some of the cutscenes are fully voice-acted while the dialogue between the protagonist you created and various NPCs is a silent affair. I’m not gonna complain since my previous subgenre favorite (again, it was Freelancer) had the same dialogue lines for almost all the “random” space station encounters. It was like TES IV Oblivion in space, to better understand how repetitive those voices and spoken lines became by the time you’d heard them countless times, no matter where you travelled. So Warlords avoids this and takes the easy way out. Far better texts and zero repetitive/annoyingly generic voices.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
If I were to discuss in detail, about the complexity and sheer variety of the gameplay in Starpoint Gemini Warlords, you’d probably not only fall asleep but also feel like you’ve just read a massive spoiler. I’ll summarize and focus on a few key features. First and foremost you’re a leader of your human faction. That doesn’t not mean that you can’t take the fight to the many enemies you shall make, but you need to understand that leading by power of personal example, won’t be as satisfying as assembling a mighty fleet and ordering them to secure a new sector for your ever-expanding ambitions.

As administrator of numerous factional assets, you’ll be responsible for the well-being and profitability of those ships and structures as well. It might sound overcomplicated but I assure you that there are very many video tutorials which you may access from within Warlords’ Codex, which shall teach you step by step, all the necessary measures and options in order to play the game at its maximum potential. You just need to be patient and don’t give up even if you met some failures along your conquest path. Resources (whether we talk of Credits or Gas, Ore etc.) are aplenty and this title’s economy is quite stable. You won’t get shifting prices and I’m glad that stock trading & market aren’t included. Those features always end up being a hindrance rather than help.

If sitting behind a proverbial desk and ordering others around sounds dull to you (and probably everyone else), our Solari Concord hero or heroine is fortunately in favor of the hands-on management style. You fly and observe those missions in person, on your own ship obviously. Speaking of which, the ships themselves are not just a sight to behold, but also come in various shapes and sizes. From the nimble gunships, to the massive freightliners and carriers. In-between, we have corvettes, cruisers, frigates and more classic nautical terms which apply not just to the space vessels but also the intricate battle mode. The ability to equip “consumable” powers and divert ship energy from shields to guns, for example, speaks volumes about the in-depth simulation I’m writing about here. There is so much more you need to discover by yourselves and I will not deny you that privilege.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
A near-flawless experience, Starpoint Gemini Warlords is the perfect combination between RPG, RTS, Economic and Space Simulation. The fact that it also does a wonderful job at instructing new players, is what sets it apart from its competitors. The price tag is fully justified, given the unestimated time you can spend within the game’s main storyline or the other open-world type scenarios in which you can focus on pure trading or bounty hunting if you wish. There are so many variables which seem to work perfectly along the gameplay mechanics which emphasize on player choices and customization. Just buy the game now or during a Steam Sale and you won’t regret it!

[h1]Summary & Rating below in the Comment Section.[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198005693291', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1496796306}
review:
The reviews and intro trailer led me to believe this was the game I've been looking for - being a fan of 4X and space sims.
I enjoyed the backstory enough for me to commit. 

The controls are unintuitive when commanding the spaceship. I enjoy learning the specifics of the game through playing, but man, I was frustrated to the point of RQ-ing before I even got that far. Spending 10 minutes of going through a 3 step process to change the options, only to go back, pressing 3 times to get to the Options menu again because I found another QOL issue, e.g. camera placement. Eventually after sitting through immersion-breaking voice scenes, I got to the combat. No words. Just. Plain disappointment. 

It's like what you learnt playing from other space sims the likes of Everspace, Elite Dangerous, and Rebel Galaxy just didn't matter, you are forced to forget all those.  The weapon projectiles, when they impact did not provide any satsifactory sound register, 80% of the time I wasn't sure if I was hitting an enemy - but like I could see their HP go down.Got that gooing for me. Crashing into a rock at max speed yields what I can only describe as a rubbery "boing".

I don't write reviews, this will be my first ever, but for the price I paid, and the year of release - I was genuinely expecting at least some good voice acting and non-jittery NPC spaceship movement. As for the controls, I suppose I had to play the other starpoint geminis series to be not absolutely frustrated by the controls.

This game has alot of potential in its concepts and story design (actually quite liked the way they delivered the character selection). To the newcomer, it feels like you NEED to have a significant amount of tenacity to get past that phase of getting used to the controls and camera angles, more so than any game I've ever played.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970613673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1991, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1991, 'last_played': 1496772114}
review:
The game is pretty much a mindless grind without any interesting gameplay to speak of. At my point in the story (which was ok up till now) the game expects me to spent gigantic amounts of ressources, to build a "death star". As you gain them over time, it would take hours of waiting until enough had trickled in and there is not enough gameplay to fill another 10 minutes. Right now all i can do is conquering space stations. These differ only in regard to their visuals. The battle plays completely the same. I don't know how often I played this same battle now, but I am fed up with it. 

What kept me playing to this point was getting the next best ship and a larger fleet. But now I have it and there is nothing interesting to do with it ... 
I really can't understand the other reviews. The game feels pretty mediocre right from the start. 
E.g.: You can't even see the stats and loadouts of the ships you build for your fleet.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968126409', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1646, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1195, 'last_played': 1496701236}
review:
Kein übles Spiel. Man kommandiert ein Großkampfschiff und fliegt dementsprechend nicht im Fighter-Style um her(obwohl das geht), sondern achtet eher auf Positionierung, Energieverwaltung und den Einsatz der Fähigkeiten. Erinnert eher daran eine mittelalterliche Fregatte zu steuern. Macht alles in allem durchaus Spass. Auch die Sektoreroberung in Kombination mit der Story ist kurzweilig, wenn auch nach einiger Zeit doch etwas monoton. 

Was leider nicht ganz passt ist die Spielbalance. Die Devs haben da in meinen Augen völlig versagt. Es gibt genau einen Weg um mit angemessenen Zeitaufwand Geld zu verdienen: Missionen. Und da mach ich auch ständig die gleiche. Alles andere dauert Vergleichsweise lang oder ist völlig ungeeignet. Bergbau, Schrottsammeln und Handel kann man völlig in der Pfeife rauchen. Da verdient man ein paar lumpige tausender, während man bei Missionen Millionen verdient, um sich ein Schiff für 65 Millionen zu leisten. Auch das Kapern lohnt nicht so richtig. Vielleicht wenn man alle Schiffstypen einsacken will. Schade. Gäbe es mehr arten Geld und Resourcen zu verdienen, würde das Spiel bestimmt mehr Spass machen. 

Auch bei den Schiffen passt die Balance nicht. Alle kosten das gleiche. Aber es gibt scheinbar bei den größeren Schiffen immer genau ein gutes. Der Rest ist einfach immer und fast überall wo es relevant ist schlechter. Da hätte man etwas mehr die stärken und schwächen herausarbeiten können, so dass verschiedene Klassen mit verschiedenen Schiffen spielen, um so den Widerspielwert etwas anzuheben.

Auch die Missionen sind schlecht Balanciert. Ich mach immer wieder die gleiche. Da töted man 3 Hanseln und einen Dreadnaught-Boss. Die bringt am meisten Penunzen und ist schnell erledigt, während andere Missionen - offenbar weil man niemanden töten muss oder was auch immer - kaum Geld bringen, obwohl der Zeitaufwand kaum unterschiedlich ist. Total willkürlich, ohne logischen nachvollziehbaren Hintergrund. Manche Missionstypen zerlegen dir auf niedrigem Level auch mal eben die Flotte, wenn du nicht aufpasst, weil einfach eine unmenge von Schiffen da rumschwirrt. 

Dazu ist die deutsche Übersetzung völlig Banane. Echt Devs. Kann mir keiner sagen, dass die paar Zeilen Story mehr als 500-1000€ kosten. 

Trotzdem hatte ich etwas Spass.

Deswegen eine Empfehlung. Persönliche Wertung: 7/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003206201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2555, 'last_played': 1567962427}
review:
Ich bin kein langjähriger Fan der Starpoint Gemini Reihe. Das kostenlose Wochenende vom 2. Teil hat mich erst dazu gebracht, auch wenn die Spiele seit längerem auf meiner Wunschliste standen, ich aber wegen der eher verhaltenen Kritiken vom Kauf absah. Irgendwie bin ich dann auf den Zug aufgesprungen das mit Warlords sicher alles besser wird.

Und was soll ich sagen, das Spiel füllt tatsächlich viele der Möglichkeiten die ich bei SG2 vermisst habe, aber natürlich tun sich auch wieder neue auf.

Der sog. RPG Anteil ist ausreichend und erschöpft sich in 4 aktive und 1 passiven Skill für jede der drei Charakterklassen. Dazu kommen eine ganze Reihe von Perks die man individuell verteilen kann, wobei die meisten ehrlich gesagt ziemlich essentiell sind so das man die große Freiheit schon etwas eingeschräntk wird.

Das bauen und wirtschaften ist leider sehr zentral auf eine Station beschränkt, die man nach und nach immer weiter ausbaut. Von hier aus schickt man seine zivilen Handelsflotten los und managed die Kriegsflotten (alles bequem von der Sternenkarte aus).
Theoretisch ist es vermutlich so gedacht, das man diese Flotten benutzt um sein Imperium auszubauen / am laufen hält, wärend man selbst etwas für den eigenen Charakter etwas entwickelt indem man z.B. Handel treibt oder diverse Missionen abschließt (Geld und Ruf grind). Wärend man dies tut, sollte man aber immer ein Auge auf den heimatlichen Sektor haben, da es kaum automations Möglichkeiten gibt. Das Spiel baut keine Schiffe, oder erledigt anfallende Handelsmissionen, ohne zutun des Spielers. Da man aber sowieso meist längere Zeit unterwegs ist, wärend man von einer Station zur nächsten fliegt, hat man auch genug Zeit sich um das Management der eigenen Leute zu kümmern.

Was mich persönlich stört sind die strikt getrennten Ressourcen, die sich tatsächlich zwischen Imperium und Spieler aufspalten. Der Charakter ist sehr auf Credits angewiesen, für die er Missionen abschließen muss. Mit dem Geld kauft man neue Schiffe oder verbessert diese, dies kostet ansonsten keine anderen Ressourcen.
Der Rest des Imperiums ist auf Gas, Erz und Material angwiesen und baut damit Schiffe, Stationen und alles andere. Diese kosten zwar immer noch eine winzige Menge an Credits, das ist aber völlig vernachlässigbar.

Warum ich jetzt meine Schiffe die ich selber fliege nicht von meinem Ingenieuren bauen lassen kann ist mir völlig schleierhaft. Dabei entfernen sich die Kosten für die einzelnen Schiffe soweit voneinander das es schnell unrealistisch wird. Während in meiner Flotte bereits das vierte Schlachtschiff vom Band läuft (kostet ca. 30k Credits, dafür etwas über 4k Materialien (was sehr viel ist), grinde ich immer noch an Missionen um mir die 25.000.000 Credits zusammen zu sparen um mir damit DAS GLEICHE Schiff zu kaufen.
Ich verstehe das man damit das Tempo und die Charakterentwicklung steuern will, aber dennoch ist das sehr plump.
Ähnlich ist es bei der Verbesserung des eigenen Schiffes. Es gibt zwar eine Menge an Ausrüstungen und Verbesserungen, aber leider scheint es auf der ganzen Karte auch überall die gleiche zu geben. Lediglich die Schiffe unterscheiden sich von Fraktion zu Fraktion und da auch primär nur im Aussehen.
Leider wird diese Auswahl an Waffen und Verbesserungen spätestens dann obsolet, wenn man das eigene Forschungszentrum anwirft, denn beinahe alles was man hier erforschen und produzieren kann ist deutlich besser als der Rest den man so kauft.
Lange erkundungen durch das System werden dadurch beinahe überflüssig, man weiss ja was es überall gibt und die Missionen sind auch überall gleich, zumal man ausschließlich mit Credits belohnt wird. Da würde ich mir schon wünschen, das es ab einem bestimmten Ruf Spezialmissionen gibt die mich mit besonderer Ausrüstung oder sogar einem Fraktionsschiff belohnen das es nicht zu kaufen gibt.

Es gibt außerdem keine Möglichkeiten überschüssige Ressourcen (und die hat man schnell mal) zu Geld zu machen. Man kann durch Handelsmissionen (für die Zivilflotten) Ressourcen untereinander tauschen (meist mit großen Verlusten, dafür gibts Ruf bei Fraktionen), aber die Möglichkeit Erz, Gas oder Materialen in Credits zu tauschen ist einfach nicht gegeben. Andersherum kann ich mir zumindest bei anderen Fraktionen für sehr viel Geld Ressourcen kaufen.

Theoretisch bietet das Spiel dem Spieler die Möglichkeit mit seinem Charakter selbst für Ressourcennachschub zu sorgen, indem man Asteroiden oder Gaswolken ernet. Praktisch ist der Gewinn aus dieser Aktionen so gering, das er völlig untergeht in der Bilanz (Mods verbessern diesen Teil des Spiels mittlerweile erheblich).

Die Story von Warlords ist... komplex. Tatsächlich hab ich recht schnell den Faden verloren und mit einem Freien Spiel angefangen, das mag aber daran liegen das ich die Story aus den Vorgängern nur unzureichend kenne und das Spiel knüpft an diese an. Grundsätzlich geht es glaube ich darum eine Verschwörung gegen die eigene Fraktion aufzudecken und diese nach einem Anschlag wieder aufzubauen.

Die Sache mit der Fraktion ist sowie ein heikles Thema. Wer nämlich denkt das er im freien Spiel auch frei wäre zu tun was er will, irrt. Man ist immer Teil der Kampagnen Fraktion, mit dem gleichen Planeten, der gleichen Station und letzendlich auch zugriff auf die gleichen Schiffe. Das und die Tatsache das die Starmap statisch ist und keine Zufallselemente enthält, macht die Wiederspielbarkeit schon recht gering. Vielleicht wird sich das später durch Mods noch beheben lassen (hoffe ich sehr).

Wer sich aber an die Mechaniken des Spiels gewöhnt hat und sich in seiner Rolle zurecht findet, wird viel Spaß mit dem Spiel haben. Die Steuerung ist gewohnt gut (wie in den Vorgängern halt) und bietet mehrere Modi sein Schiff zu befehligen, so das für jeden was dabei sein sollte.
Was ich persönlich vermisse ist die Möglichkeit Offiziere anzuheuern die mir auf meinem Schiff Boni bringen, das hatte einfach einen netten Touch und bot Atmosphere. Zumal man hier auch direkt die Station mit Offizieren ausstatten könnte und so neben den Warmastern (Charakterschiffe in der eigenen Flotte wenn man so will) ein paar Gesichter in der eigenen Fraktion hätte, die ansonsten recht anonym bleibt.

Ich richte da meine Hoffnung auf die Modder-Community und darauf das die Entwickler hier noch nachbessern und sei es als DLC.

review: I purchased this game early, played for a couple hours and decided to wait until the full release.  I will say I'm very impressed with the product.  It's an empire building game with a focus on space combat.  There are a couple minor bugs that I've noticed, but nothing that makes the game unplayable.  I would give this game a 8/10 with room for improvements as the Developer continues to release updates.  This is the first game of the series that I have played and I'm now considering going back and playing some of the others.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050681109', 'num_games_owned': 491, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2671, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1987, 'last_played': 1542097708}
review:
This game is a fun mix of 4x and space-sim lite. The are varied ships, different weapons classes, and unlockable research that you can use to customize your ships. The 4x element is well done, if a bit repetitive. Buy this game if you're a fan of space combat with fleets and 4x elements. 

The biggest con in my eyes is trade; it is not worth your time past buying a freighter in the early game to trade between Phaenaros and Confodia.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032112576', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 8085, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1912, 'last_played': 1497901610}
review:
Consider me hooked!  

I have been looking for something that brought together my favorite aspects of several approaches to a vibrant sci-fi universe including recent 4x titles such as Endless Space, decision making and RPG elements found in ME and Horizon and free-roam flight/combat sim aspects in the vein of Elite D and S Citizen--and boom Starpoint Gemini Warlords delivers it all well enough to keep me invested.  

Make no mistake--I do not see myself bringing the HOTAS into Warlords but this tickles every fancy I have ever held for massive Capital ship combat with RISK-like startegy and Warlords already has content where other universe's have felt increasingly empty and sparse of late.  The voice acting may be intermittent and there is a lot of reading--but that has become routine for titles with as much lore as Gemini has going for it.

Be prepared for a relatively (and arguably thankfully) slow start out of the gate and know you will definitely prosper here if you have experience playing any of the titles listed above over an absolute newcomer, but cut yourself some slack and watch a few YouTube videos before you take on anything...and know--from where I am sitting right now--this has been one game I am glad I invested the time to learn!

author: {'steamid': '76561198052486456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1496671853}
review:
Das Spiel ist es nicht wer, gekauft zu werden. Wer auf Deutsch spielt wird sich zuerst einmal mit einer Übersetzung herumschlagen, die wirkt als hätte ein 5 Jähriger daran gearbeitet. Simpelste Wörter sind vollkommen undefinierbar verunstaltet worden.

der Zweite Punkt ist die Steuerung. Einfach grausam, damit klar zu kommen dürfte eine ganze Weile dauern. 
Ich wage es nicht, dieses Spiel länger zu spielen als ich es getan habe, selbst das Tutorial ist eine absolute Qual.

Es gibt hierfür keine Kaufempfehlung, sucht euch lieber etwas anständiges.

Aus Spielen, die schon so massive Rechtschreibfehler aufweisen, kann nichts gutes entstehen, klare Warnung vor einem Kauf.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970752078', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 1568, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1568, 'last_played': 1496674849}
review:
Great game, here are some pointers for starters:
1. Make sure you have enough money for enhancements before upgrading your ship.
2. Consider capturing ships, it's a good way to gain extra materials and money (plus you can steal your next ship instead of buying one).
3. Dont forget to install extra turrets on your ship. 
4. Keep your civilian fleet bussy, it is a good way to earn extra materials.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012860142', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 3429, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2890, 'last_played': 1498463598}
review:
This is what makes SG Warlords such a great achievement in my opinion:

* The empire building is enjoyable (and so is galactic domination). 
* The space combat is engaging after some in-game tutorials, and customising of keybindings/camera settings.
* Side missions and random "mystery" events keep you busy.
* The game world and characters actually have personality (missing in the space genre since freelancer) 
* #taraiscute
* It's not easy to beat this game (especially in the harder difficulty it's a protracted journey, much like Mount and Blade)

Make sure you try out the different camera views to make combat enjoyable for you. I personally preferred zooming the camera out to max, keeping it in normal view, reallocating power to shields and weapons (slows down the craziness a bit), setting light weapons to auto-fire, and flying around the target using special skills. 

The directional shields and heavy weapon turrets are probably the most unique thing about the combat in starpoint. It encourages you to keep on the move and attack enemies from different angles to make full use of shield power and turret ammo.

I also found the combat more enjoyable when you get into the bigger ships, because the camera can be zoomed out further, and you can keep a better view of the battle. Also, I would  suggest re-speccing your skills to get the exact ones you want (regardless of character class), and making good use of consumables, like damage and shield boosters.

This game's storyline aint too shabby (by space game standards it's superb!). There's even a bit of humour. I'd love it if the devs made some special side missions involving the main NPC characters (especially Tara Higgs). That hashtag again: #taraiscute

Cons:

* Lack of fleet control.
* Diplomatic options are sparse
* Combat doesnt really require different tactics for different enemies, which can make it repetitive.
* You can't customise the skills and leveling up of NPC fleet members (yet ! *crosses fingers*)

Overall though, this game is plenty of hours worth of fun right from the get go, and it will surely be built upon by the devs and the modding community. Well done LGM.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044237702', 'num_games_owned': 1123, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 1687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1522, 'last_played': 1496515379}
review:
狱长守站未半而中道背锅，今议会三分，康州疲弊，此诚危急存亡之秋也。然绿茶婊崔丝不懈于内，爆破者妮卡忘身于外者，盖追狱长之殊遇，欲报之于汝也。诚宜开张圣听，以光狱长遗德，恢弘志士之气，不宜妄自菲薄，引喻失义，以塞忠谏之路也。

　据点小站，俱为一体，布防开发，不宜异同。若有宇宙海贼及为侵略者，宜付舰队论其惩处，以昭阁下铁血之理，不宜偏私，使内外异法也。 

　康州众人，皆为良实，志虑忠纯，是以狱长简拔以遗阁下。愚以为内政开发，事无大小，悉以咨之，然后施行，必能裨补阙漏，有所广益。 

　将军莱纳德，性行淑均，晓畅军事，试用于昔日，狱长称之曰能，是以众议举宠为督。愚以为攻城略地，悉以咨之，必能使行阵和睦，优劣得所。 

　　跑任务，卖飞船，此康州所以和谐也；光装逼，不打架，此黑色誓言所以倾颓也。狱长在时，每与臣论此事，未尝不叹息痛恨于议会也。九号组织、辛迪加、堡垒组织、保皇派，此悉安分守己之盟友，愿阁下亲之信之，则康州之隆，可计日而待也。 

　臣本屌丝，躬耕于菲球，苟全性命于乱世，不求闻达于诸侯。狱长不以臣卑鄙，猥自枉屈，三顾臣于船坞之中，咨臣以造船之事，由是感激，遂许狱长以驱驰。后值倾覆，受任于败军之际，奉命于危难之间，尔来二十有一年矣。 

　狱长知臣谨慎，故寄臣以大事也。受命以来，夙夜忧叹，恐托付不效，以伤狱长之明，故建比邻国星，深入敌后。今北方已定，兵甲已足，当集结舰队，南下扫荡，庶竭驽钝，攘除奸凶，兴复康州，平定议会之乱。此臣所以报狱长而忠阁下之职分也。至于斟酌损益，进尽忠言，则崔丝，妮卡等之任也。 

　愿阁下托臣以讨贼兴复之效，不效则治臣之罪，以告狱长之恩。若无兴德之言，则责崔丝，妮卡等之慢，以彰其咎；阁下亦宜自谋，以咨诹善道，察纳雅言，深追狱长之愿。臣不胜受恩感激。 

　今当远离，临表涕零，不知所言。

-------------------------------------------

[h1]几点感想：[/h1]

1.	比上代丰富一些，也好玩一些。

2.	三大妈汉化出了，基本完整，百度一下，你就知道。

3.	电脑的AI不是很聪明。

4.	登船小分队很imba，练好了以后专治各种不服。

5.	科普一下：其实双子星系列和九几年一个叫做[自由枪骑兵]的游戏很相似，当然无论是画面上还是系统的精细度上都更加现代一些。

6.	剧情完了就是自由模式了，而且剧情不长，但是打剧情最后需要2W5舰队实力，后期比起前代的星际跑商来说有意思了不少，不过可能因为AI比较死板的原因，可能占领一半地图之后，感觉就少有新鲜感了。

7.	早期多跑任务多升级，没事多去尝试登敌人船，成功了经验给的多，成功不了的就掠夺。前期多去登船可以解锁技能，后期轻松。

-------------------------------------------

[b]总体来说还行，节奏不是那么的紧张，喜欢星际题材的可以购入，注意这个游戏没有什么4X成分。[/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198006217347', 'num_games_owned': 1157, 'num_reviews': 213, 'playtime_forever': 4279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4208, 'last_played': 1498736945}
review:
It is a good arcade space game with elements of 4X. There are multiple options at the start of a new game including Free Roam and Story Mode. The story is okay and is enjoyable to get through apart from the last few missions which are a real drag. The meat of the game is in Free Roam which you can do after you go through the story, this is where you will have a great deal of fun there are over 150 space stations to conquer in addition to at least a dozen planets. As you conquer, your empire expands which brings in additional resources which could be spent on expanding your fleet, building and upgrading defensive and resource generating space stations, hub construction and research. Some research costs blow out to an insane amount but once you get your economy going you will be making a killing. The enemies aren't static, there are faction in this game and if they are at war with you they will attempt to attack your fleets and take over your regions. I quite enjoyed the 4X aspect of this game and I think that it makes it a better game than its predecessor - SPG2. The combat isn't as nuanced as something like X3:AP but it is still quite satisfying.

The issues I have with the game is that it is glitchy, I have two systems I game on, the desktop with GTX1080 and i7 and a laptop with GTX1060 and i7. Both of those systems handily exceed the specs on Store Page for this. The desktop runs this game on 2560 x 1440 with high settings reasonably well but with fairly frequent crashes, the performance on the laptop is far more problematic. It runs the game in 1920 x 1080 and it runs it poorly even on low settings, the framerate is very poor and it also experiences frequent crashes which necessasite a hard restart on the laptop. Updating Nvidia drivers did not help this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052917826', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 8857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3740, 'last_played': 1538727727}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009918681', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 5266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4243, 'last_played': 1606345352}
review:
In many ways Warlords is a 'thank you' letter to its fanbase. Many of us have been around since SPG 1 and have watched this franchise grow and evolve. I was an Early Access supporter of SPG2, and also of Warlords. During EA, and GA of SPG2 there were so many 'wouldn't it be cool' topics that LGM essentially commited themselves to making these (sometimes outlandish) requests an actual game.

From there, Warlords was born. It's a charming mix of 4X light and 3rd person space shooting, with a decent dose of RPG thrown in. I'm many hours in, and I have barely scratched the surface. The game won't be for everyone tho - there is a lot of grind (which I happen to enjoy) and for the most part it isn't tedious. There's a campaign, which I always play as a frame for free roam, and many actual free roam options. 

It does take some getting used to, many people say the camera is 'broken' but it's not really, it's just the way the series works and you have to get accustomed to it. If you bought it hoping it might be patched out, I'm afraid you're mistaken! Once you grasp it tho, it really is  a lot of fun.

The game also supports 21:9 right out of the box, supports SLI via AFR2 and looks gorgeous at 3440x1440. I know the game is only going to get better as more content is released and a few features are added (bounties!). 

I wrote a deeper review on SPG2, and many of those points still stand here. I'm having a blast, and thank LGM for sending this letter!

author: {'steamid': '76561198073961079', 'num_games_owned': 630, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 807, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 807, 'last_played': 1494762136}
review:
跟1代、2代差不多的我就不写了。

1.可以升级基地，研发科技，包括增强武力、新的机型（AI队友）、资源收入，造AI队友飞船，怼他个2w战力的舰队横扫天下哼哼（并不
2.可以指派完成大地图上的任务，视你的指挥点数为限
3.可以在驾驶状态对队友打开菜单选Follow me，或者地图状态下点舰队图标跟自己座驾集合
4.可以在地图状态下选舰队去攻打任何你想打的地方，打之前最好看看战斗力~~最好是造几艘小飞机派出去开地图，反正燃料也用不完
5.新的技能树，界面太丑没关注
6.虫洞上面可以建造星门，没有星门的虫洞只能定向传送到对应出口，有星门的话可以自己选择目的地（目的地也要有星门）
7.要占领一个区域只要去打下前哨站就行，但是可能会有独立基地存在，需要单独攻略，独立基地各种加成，甚至有船厂，分担本部基地的建造队列~
8.千万不要亲自去攻打哪怕稍微有点规模的基地，基地导弹会舍弃所有AI队友全部跑来教你做人
9.记得勾兑各方中立势力，达成贸易后加成非常可观
10.多带点T-Drive，逃命必备
11.妈的AI队友飞船比我的漂亮

凭玩过的印象写的，上次玩是大半个月前了，老婆管着不好找机会玩游戏啊
最后，贸易系统就是渣渣，从1代开始到现在都是

author: {'steamid': '76561198077622398', 'num_games_owned': 107, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 6230, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4879, 'last_played': 1498368863}
review: For a blend of RPG and 4X Space strategy Game, Star point Gemini Warlords appealed me from the beginning. I have not played original Star point Gemini and punched few hours with Star point Gemini 2. But this game attracted me for its visual elements. After a long early access period, post release version lives upto it's potential. The game has every element of good game great visuals, Random Encounters, intriguing story line. One time you will dominate in the battle , next time you will be just blasted of and have to flee. It has improved upon its predecessors. The game is also performing well in mid and low level gaming rigs. There are small bugs and glitches here and there; but I have every hope that the devs will sort those out. The game has great value for money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999505453', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 116, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 116, 'last_played': 1496434497}
review:
Concept and vision is cool, but the execution leaves a lot to be desired.

Incredibly clunky UI, unintuitive camera and aiming, a lacking tutorial, horrible voice acting, uncompelling two-dimensional characters and story are just some of the things that makes the game nearly unplayable.

I cannot recommend this game in its current form.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037240021', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1132, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1130, 'last_played': 1497683922}
review:
Трудно оценить эту игру, даже захватив половину галактики... .  Всё же кроме цели заполучить корабль больше, чем твое корыто, некоторых вещей в данной игре действительно не хватает.

Игра достойна внимания, если вы любитель жанра *создай свою армаду и разнеси всё к чертям*

Сильным недостатком я посчитал ущербный AI собственного крыла, т.к некоторые виды кораблей даже не стремятся в бой, а отлетают на огромное расстояние и смотрят на то, как ты своим корытом закрываешь большую половину урона, дабы твой флот не разнесли (Это я говорю про Дредноуты и Авианосцы. У вторых есть ещё проблема не выпускать истребители) . Это относится и к захватам станций - AI не будет делать всю работу за вас, даже если они будут рядом с надоедливыми аванпостами - они вам просто не помогут. Но частые фиксы дают надежду на исправление этого недостатка. *Ведь почти каждый хочет сидеть в кресле ничего не делая и наслаждаться зрелищем, возможно я и ошибаюсь*

author: {'steamid': '76561198045478468', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 7972, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7972, 'last_played': 1512076837}
review:
I actually liked this game initially. But I didn't play it more than a few hundred hours(I played SP for 1.5k hours). There was something off about it which I couldn't quite put my finger on.
Years later I come to see what it was... It didn't have a story anymore, not like what SPs used to have. What I remember from the old SP, was exactly that and this had become an empire building like many other games of the same genre.
That caused the ships, especially the player ship to be infinitesimally insignificant across the universe for the universe to feel alive and in turn, the universe had to have a static simulation.
I also had expected to see some improvement in aesthetics due to the era of the release however, albeit subjective, I didn't like the art of any of the ships.
I may try the next game but will do so very carefully.
developer_response:
Hi. Please allow me several questions:
1.Do all the problems persist even with the latest patch, released today?
2.Are you running any mods? (this is related to the perks overlapping issue)
3.Can you please send the game log.txt to customersupport@starpointgemini.com when an issue occurs?

I'm baffled by the game freezing on pressing the Load game button. I haven't encountered it ever and I haven't noticed it being mentioned on the discussion board. I could have missed it, of course, and I apologize if I did.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999654663', 'num_games_owned': 455, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1496349748}
review:
Wish there was a neutral option for the review system.

Honestly the game suffers from a wide variety of issues ranging from clunky-as-fuck interface and camera to realy bad voiceacting and no form of introduction at all to the universe or the game. The learning curve is very steep due to this along with the clunky interface. I realy wanted to like this but in the end i ended opting for a refund as the whole game gives of a beta feeling. Like its missing the finishing touch on every single aspect.

That said my playtime is realy low so i might be plain wrong. Might also be that this game series just isnt for me and im a whiny ass. Pains me to downvote something that has such a good idea but i cant recommend something that i myself refunded.
developer_response:
Hi GrumpyPirate

Thank you for explaining your thoughts and decision. I appreciate it. I understand your decision and, frankly, Warlords is a niche title as in not-for-everyone's-taste. The other things you mention is something we're working on. We hope to iron out all the kinks and quirks as soon as possible, and add more free content to boot.

Thanks for the review again!

review:
While lacking in a bit of polish, its a fantastic game and one of the few to really improve greatly through Early Access. Think of it as a more arcade like X/Eve. But you can actually hop on and feel like you have accomplished something. Plus the RTS aspect allows you to get some real map painting going, who dosent love conquering everything in your colour?


The Devs do excellent outreach and have a fun product that hasnt plenty of room for further content. As further updates become available this game will become a long term time sink.

review: I dont write many reviews, but this game is honestly worthy of one. Even on my low end laptop i am having a blast playing it, and i am anxious to get my gaming pc running again so i can see the game in its full glory. It has quite a bit of depth, and it would be really awesome to see more complexity put into ship builds and player talents and skills. I would also be interested to see more weapons and classes added. Maybe even bigger ships than we already have in the game. I'm a huge fan of space games such as eve and so on, this fills my single player itch for that category, and needeless to say, if there were super super super caps, with tons and tons of weapons, well id be in heaven. Till then ill just see how big of a fleet i can make since im used to 500v 1k ship fights :) :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198006561843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 3660, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1588, 'last_played': 1699051083}
review:
Starpoint Gemini 2 was the first game I installed when I finally saved enough to get a new PC worth owning, I spent many hours playing it and didnt think much could have been done to improve on it. I was wrong.


Warlords is everything 2 had with full empire managment on top, build ships, conquer territiory, research new tech and diplomacy.

As others have said its not a million miles away from Mount and Blade in space which is a pretty good thing to be compared to.


Highly recommend.

Also get the Rebel galaxy soundtrack mod, as awesome as that game was it was too short.  This compares nicely.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972270881', 'num_games_owned': 832, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 2479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2207, 'last_played': 1517832058}
review:
Excellent game! The free offer for SPG 2 piqued my interest in this company and game, as while SPG2 had a lot of interesting core mechanics, ideas and the "mount and blade in space" kind of vibe, it felt barren. It seemed more in line with a game that can be a lot better given more time and more budget.

Warlords seems to be that exact upgrade and is a significant improvement over the 2nd game. The 4X aspect isn't overly complicated, but keeps you pretty busy while trying to figure out how to take over the map. Big fights are suitably big and boomy, and the classes all play out very differently in style. It allows you to set your own personal goal and advance towards it, whether it be full on conquest, being a random trader, merc for hire, solo beast, etc. It's nice.

My negatives of the game are a pair of things, which I think over time the developers can definitely fix:

-It becomes very difficult to make progress if you level too fast and go into territories to conquer them too late. The leveling scales everything up, and if you've spent a good amount of time doing freelance work the game kind of imbalances in the AI's favour as suddenly they're throwing out dreads while you're struggling to make enough resources to even get one out. I think this was partially my own fault though, as I wasn't really being aggressive in the early game and probably focused far too much in macro. Still, it's a slippery slope and easy to get caught in that weird deadzone where it's a slog.

-In the release version of the game there seems to be a bug where in big fights, music, various sound effects etc just don't play, so fights end up being silent in some aspects but really loud in others. I have a dedicated Sound Card (Audigy FX) so it may be something to do with that, or some setting in DirectSound where not enough channels are firing off. No idea, it's weird and throws me off a lot though!

Apart from those issues, I think the game is great and will continue to improve a tonne as devs add in expansions, DLC and things like that. If I catch any other bugs or issues I'll be happy to throw out some more feedback when I'm free from work and general life things.

Highly recommended.

Pozdrav iz japana jednog srpskog prijatelja, game ti je super!

author: {'steamid': '76561198103980186', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 1057, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 701, 'last_played': 1497171002}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993794599', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 7273, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2553, 'last_played': 1529676653}
review:
Ok, so let me preface this with an admission: I bought SPG2... and just could not get into it. Something about the learning curve/mechanics which just didn't gel with me. So trust me when I say that I reluctantly purchased this game hoping for the best...

And boy! Was I surprised!

Whilst the gameplay changes may be hard to spot at first, this game is 100 x more enjoyable than the previous offerings. I'd even go far as to say that it is one of the most enjoyable experiences I've had for quite some time. The combat is solid, and challenging even on Normal Difficulties. The range of ships are diverse. The soundtrack is great.

Then there is the new 'omg lets take over that because I NEED more gas' part of the game.
There is something oh-so satisfying about rocking up in your Frigate, Destroyer, Cruiser... (thats where I am at right now) with a decent assortment of weapons and cruising on over the border to some enemy territory to say 'ello. Immediately ships (security forces) T-drive in and go about doing their job. Its a tense few minutes as I assess the fleet coming towards me (how many gunships? how many corvettes? oh crap is that a pair of cruisers as well? ffffffffffffff!!!

Manage to survive by the skin of your teeth, attempt to fly home only to clip an asteroid/fly through a radiation belt and you die.

10/10 would recommend!
developer_response:
Hey there!

I'm soooooo happy to see players who didn't [i]dig[/i] Starpoint 2, can get into Warlords. That tells us we're improving :). Thanks for posting your review. We appreciate it a lot and we hope future content updates will keep you enjoying the game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197961415346', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1496130723}
review:
The controls are fairly awkward, and the game seems to be missing any form of target assist that helps you to determine where you need to aim to 'lead' the target and actually hit it. Trying to hit something while it's moving around incredibly quickly around you is practically impossible, it's hard enough maneuvering around just so you can keep your badly placed turrets in an arc where they can even shoot. This means you are forced to use the automatic firing to have any chance, and thus you're barely even playing a game, it's almost all automated. Travel times are quite slow.

I also found myself blocked by progressing through the campaign on the mission where you first get your corvette(like the third mission I think), as the enemies you face(on default difficulty) are so powerful the weapons you have do literally nothing to them. It's a little strange, as there's only the one ship you can reasonably buy at the time and it can't do anything; it's possible I just chose the wrong class at the start, the stealth one, and so didn't have enough firepower to hurt the enemy. A freeform game may not have this problem, but the campaign balance is off a bit.

I don't know if any of the strategic layer is good or not, as I didn't reach that point.
developer_response:
Hi Devoras,

Sorry to hear the game disappointed you. It was definitely not our intention for this to happen. We'll continue to work on the game, both the freeroam mode and the campaign to fix glitches and [i]iron out[/i] the rough edges and I hope, in time, you'll give the game another shot.

In any case, thank you for posting your review. Every one of these we receive helps us improve the game.
